1.verse: The Beginning of the World - In the beginning God created the sky and the earth.

2.verse: The earth was empty and had no form. Darkness covered the ocean, and God’s Spirit was moving over the water.

3.verse: Then God said, “Let there be light,” and there was light.

4.verse: God saw that the light was good, so he divided the light from the darkness.

5.verse: God named the light “day” and the darkness “night.” Evening passed, and morning came. This was the first day.

6.verse: Then God said, “Let there be something to divide the water in two.”

7.verse: So God made the air and placed some of the water above the air and some below it.

8.verse: God named the air “sky.” Evening passed, and morning came. This was the second day.

9.verse: Then God said, “Let the water under the sky be gathered together so the dry land will appear.” And it happened.

10.verse: God named the dry land “earth” and the water that was gathered together “seas.” God saw that this was good.

11.verse: Then God said, “Let the earth produce plants—some to make grain for seeds and others to make fruits with seeds in them. Every seed will produce more of its own kind of plant.” And it happened.

12.verse: The earth produced plants with grain for seeds and trees that made fruits with seeds in them. Each seed grew its own kind of plant. God saw that all this was good.

13.verse: Evening passed, and morning came. This was the third day.

14.verse: Then God said, “Let there be lights in the sky to separate day from night. These lights will be used for signs, seasons, days, and years.

15.verse: They will be in the sky to give light to the earth.” And it happened.

16.verse: So God made the two large lights. He made the brighter light to rule the day and made the smaller light to rule the night. He also made the stars.

17.verse: God put all these in the sky to shine on the earth,

18.verse: to rule over the day and over the night, and to separate the light from the darkness. God saw that all these things were good.

19.verse: Evening passed, and morning came. This was the fourth day.

20.verse: Then God said, “Let the water be filled with living things, and let birds fly in the air above the earth.”

21.verse: So God created the large sea animals and every living thing that moves in the sea. The sea is filled with these living things, with each one producing more of its own kind. He also made every bird that flies, and each bird produced more of its own kind. God saw that this was good.

22.verse: God blessed them and said, “Have many young ones so that you may grow in number. Fill the water of the seas, and let the birds grow in number on the earth.”

23.verse: Evening passed, and morning came. This was the fifth day.

24.verse: Then God said, “Let the earth be filled with animals, each producing more of its own kind. Let there be tame animals and small crawling animals and wild animals, and let each produce more of its kind.” And it happened.

25.verse: So God made the wild animals, the tame animals, and all the small crawling animals to produce more of their own kind. God saw that this was good.

26.verse: Then God said, “Let us make human beings in our image and likeness. And let them rule over the fish in the sea and the birds in the sky, over the tame animals, over all the earth, and over all the small crawling animals on the earth.”

27.verse: So God created human beings in his image. In the image of God he created them. He created them male and female.

28.verse: God blessed them and said, “Have many children and grow in number. Fill the earth and be its master. Rule over the fish in the sea and over the birds in the sky and over every living thing that moves on the earth.”

29.verse: God said, “Look, I have given you all the plants that have grain for seeds and all the trees whose fruits have seeds in them. They will be food for you.

30.verse: I have given all the green plants as food for every wild animal, every bird of the air, and every small crawling animal.” And it happened.

31.verse: God looked at everything he had made, and it was very good. Evening passed, and morning came. This was the sixth day.

1.verse: The Seventh Day—Rest - So the sky, the earth, and all that filled them were finished.

2.verse: By the seventh day God finished the work he had been doing, so he rested from all his work.

3.verse: God blessed the seventh day and made it a holy day, because on that day he rested from all the work he had done in creating the world.

4.verse: The First People - This is the story of the creation of the sky and the earth. When the LORD God first made the earth and the sky,

5.verse: there were still no plants on the earth. Nothing was growing in the fields because the LORD God had not yet made it rain on the land. And there was no person to care for the ground,

6.verse: but a mist would rise up from the earth and water all the ground.

7.verse: Then the LORD God took dust from the ground and formed a man from it. He breathed the breath of life into the man’s nose, and the man became a living person.

8.verse: Then the LORD God planted a garden in the east, in a place called Eden, and put the man he had formed into it.

9.verse: The LORD God caused every beautiful tree and every tree that was good for food to grow out of the ground. In the middle of the garden, God put the tree that gives life and also the tree that gives the knowledge of good and evil.

10.verse: A river flowed through Eden and watered the garden. From there the river branched out to become four rivers.

11.verse: The first river, named Pishon, flows around the whole land of Havilah, where there is gold.

12.verse: The gold of that land is excellent. Bdellium and onyx are also found there.

13.verse: The second river, named Gihon, flows around the whole land of Cush.

14.verse: The third river, named Tigris, flows out of Assyria toward the east. The fourth river is the Euphrates.

15.verse: The LORD God put the man in the garden of Eden to care for it and work it.

16.verse: The LORD God commanded him, “You may eat the fruit from any tree in the garden,

17.verse: but you must not eat the fruit from the tree which gives the knowledge of good and evil. If you ever eat fruit from that tree, you will die!”

18.verse: The First Woman - Then the LORD God said, “It is not good for the man to be alone. I will make a helper who is right for him.”

19.verse: From the ground God formed every wild animal and every bird in the sky, and he brought them to the man so the man could name them. Whatever the man called each living thing, that became its name.

20.verse: The man gave names to all the tame animals, to the birds in the sky, and to all the wild animals. But Adam did not find a helper that was right for him.

21.verse: So the LORD God caused the man to sleep very deeply, and while he was asleep, God removed one of the man’s ribs. Then God closed up the man’s skin at the place where he took the rib.

22.verse: The LORD God used the rib from the man to make a woman, and then he brought the woman to the man.

23.verse: And the man said, “Now, this is someone whose bones came from my bones, whose body came from my body. I will call her ‘woman,’ because she was taken out of man.”

24.verse: So a man will leave his father and mother and be united with his wife, and the two will become one body.

25.verse: The man and his wife were naked, but they were not ashamed.

1.verse: The Beginning of Sin - Now the snake was the most clever of all the wild animals the LORD God had made. One day the snake said to the woman, “Did God really say that you must not eat fruit from any tree in the garden?”

2.verse: The woman answered the snake, “We may eat fruit from the trees in the garden.

3.verse: But God told us, ‘You must not eat fruit from the tree that is in the middle of the garden. You must not even touch it, or you will die.’”

4.verse: But the snake said to the woman, “You will not die.

5.verse: God knows that if you eat the fruit from that tree, you will learn about good and evil and you will be like God!”

6.verse: The woman saw that the tree was beautiful, that its fruit was good to eat, and that it would make her wise. So she took some of its fruit and ate it. She also gave some of the fruit to her husband who was with her, and he ate it.

7.verse: Then, it was as if their eyes were opened. They realized they were naked, so they sewed fig leaves together and made something to cover themselves.

8.verse: Then they heard the LORD God walking in the garden during the cool part of the day, and the man and his wife hid from the LORD God among the trees in the garden.

9.verse: But the LORD God called to the man and said, “Where are you?”

10.verse: The man answered, “I heard you walking in the garden, and I was afraid because I was naked, so I hid.”

11.verse: God asked, “Who told you that you were naked? Did you eat fruit from the tree from which I commanded you not to eat?”

12.verse: The man said, “You gave this woman to me and she gave me fruit from the tree, so I ate it.”

13.verse: Then the LORD God said to the woman, “How could you have done such a thing?” She answered, “The snake tricked me, so I ate the fruit.”

14.verse: The LORD God said to the snake, “Because you did this, a curse will be put on you. You will be cursed as no other animal, tame or wild, will ever be. You will crawl on your stomach, and you will eat dust all the days of your life.

15.verse: I will make you and the woman enemies to each other. Your descendants and her descendants will be enemies. One of her descendants will crush your head, and you will bite his heel.”

16.verse: Then God said to the woman, “I will cause you to have much trouble when you are pregnant, and when you give birth to children, you will have great pain. You will greatly desire your husband, but he will rule over you.”

17.verse: Then God said to the man, “You listened to what your wife said, and you ate fruit from the tree from which I commanded you not to eat. “So I will put a curse on the ground, and you will have to work very hard for your food. In pain you will eat its food all the days of your life.

18.verse: The ground will produce thorns and weeds for you, and you will eat the plants of the field.

19.verse: You will sweat and work hard for your food. Later you will return to the ground, because you were taken from it. You are dust, and when you die, you will return to the dust.”

20.verse: The man named his wife Eve, because she was the mother of all the living.

21.verse: The LORD God made clothes from animal skins for the man and his wife and dressed them.

22.verse: Then the LORD God said, “Humans have become like one of us; they know good and evil. We must keep them from eating some of the fruit from the tree of life, or they will live forever.”

23.verse: So the LORD God forced Adam out of the garden of Eden to work the ground from which he was taken.

24.verse: After God forced humans out of the garden, he placed angels and a sword of fire that flashed around in every direction on its eastern border. This kept people from getting to the tree of life.

1.verse: The First Family - Adam had sexual relations with his wife Eve, and she became pregnant and gave birth to Cain. Eve said, “With the LORD’s help, I have given birth to a man.”

2.verse: After that, Eve gave birth to Cain’s brother Abel. Abel took care of flocks, and Cain became a farmer.

3.verse: Later, Cain brought some food from the ground as a gift to God.

4.verse: Abel brought the best parts from some of the firstborn of his flock. The LORD accepted Abel and his gift,

5.verse: but he did not accept Cain and his gift. So Cain became very angry and felt rejected.

6.verse: The LORD asked Cain, “Why are you angry? Why do you look so unhappy?

7.verse: If you do things well, I will accept you, but if you do not do them well, sin is ready to attack you. Sin wants you, but you must rule over it.”

8.verse: Cain said to his brother Abel, “Let’s go out into the field.” While they were out in the field, Cain attacked his brother Abel and killed him.

9.verse: Later, the LORD said to Cain, “Where is your brother Abel?” Cain answered, “I don’t know. Is it my job to take care of my brother?”

10.verse: Then the LORD said, “What have you done? Your brother’s blood is crying out to me from the ground.

11.verse: And now you will be cursed in your work with the ground, the same ground where your brother’s blood fell and where your hands killed him.

12.verse: You will work the ground, but it will not grow good crops for you anymore, and you will wander around on the earth.”

13.verse: Then Cain said to the LORD, “This punishment is more than I can stand!

14.verse: Today you have forced me to stop working the ground, and now I must hide from you. I must wander around on the earth, and anyone who meets me can kill me.”

15.verse: The LORD said to Cain, “No! If anyone kills you, I will punish that person seven times more.” Then the LORD put a mark on Cain warning anyone who met him not to kill him.

16.verse: Cain’s Family - So Cain went away from the LORD and lived in the land of Nod, east of Eden.

17.verse: He had sexual relations with his wife, and she became pregnant and gave birth to Enoch. At that time Cain was building a city, which he named after his son Enoch.

18.verse: Enoch had a son named Irad, Irad had a son named Mehujael, Mehujael had a son named Methushael, and Methushael had a son named Lamech.

19.verse: Lamech married two women, Adah and Zillah.

20.verse: Adah gave birth to Jabal, who became the first person to live in tents and raise cattle.

21.verse: Jabal’s brother was Jubal, the first person to play the harp and flute.

22.verse: Zillah gave birth to Tubal-Cain, who made tools out of bronze and iron. The sister of Tubal-Cain was Naamah.

23.verse: Lamech said to his wives: “Adah and Zillah, hear my voice! You wives of Lamech, listen to what I say. I killed a man for wounding me, a young man for hitting me.

24.verse: If Cain’s killer is punished seven times, then Lamech’s killer will be punished seventy-seven times.”

25.verse: Adam and Eve Have a New Son - Adam had sexual relations with his wife Eve again, and she gave birth to a son. She named him Seth and said, “God has given me another child. He will take the place of Abel, who was killed by Cain.”

26.verse: Seth also had a son, and they named him Enosh. At that time people began to pray to the LORD.

1.verse: Adam’s Family History - This is the family history of Adam. When God created human beings, he made them in his own likeness.

2.verse: He created them male and female, and on that day he blessed them and named them human beings.

3.verse: When Adam was 130 years old, he became the father of another son in his likeness and image, and Adam named him Seth.

4.verse: After Seth was born, Adam lived 800 years and had other sons and daughters.

5.verse: So Adam lived a total of 930 years, and then he died.

6.verse: When Seth was 105 years old, he had a son named Enosh.

7.verse: After Enosh was born, Seth lived 807 years and had other sons and daughters.

8.verse: So Seth lived a total of 912 years, and then he died.

9.verse: When Enosh was 90 years old, he had a son named Kenan.

10.verse: After Kenan was born, Enosh lived 815 years and had other sons and daughters.

11.verse: So Enosh lived a total of 905 years, and then he died.

12.verse: When Kenan was 70 years old, he had a son named Mahalalel.

13.verse: After Mahalalel was born, Kenan lived 840 years and had other sons and daughters.

14.verse: So Kenan lived a total of 910 years, and then he died.

15.verse: When Mahalalel was 65 years old, he had a son named Jared.

16.verse: After Jared was born, Mahalalel lived 830 years and had other sons and daughters.

17.verse: So Mahalalel lived a total of 895 years, and then he died.

18.verse: When Jared was 162 years old, he had a son named Enoch.

19.verse: After Enoch was born, Jared lived 800 years and had other sons and daughters.

20.verse: So Jared lived a total of 962 years, and then he died.

21.verse: When Enoch was 65 years old, he had a son named Methuselah.

22.verse: After Methuselah was born, Enoch walked with God 300 years more and had other sons and daughters.

23.verse: So Enoch lived a total of 365 years.

24.verse: Enoch walked with God; one day Enoch could not be found, because God took him.

25.verse: When Methuselah was 187 years old, he had a son named Lamech.

26.verse: After Lamech was born, Methuselah lived 782 years and had other sons and daughters.

27.verse: So Methuselah lived a total of 969 years, and then he died.

28.verse: When Lamech was 182, he had a son.

29.verse: Lamech named his son Noah and said, “He will comfort us in our work, which comes from the ground the LORD has cursed.”

30.verse: After Noah was born, Lamech lived 595 years and had other sons and daughters.

31.verse: So Lamech lived a total of 777 years, and then he died.

32.verse: After Noah was 500 years old, he became the father of Shem, Ham, and Japheth.

1.verse: The Human Race Becomes Evil - The number of people on earth began to grow, and daughters were born to them.

2.verse: When the sons of God saw that these girls were beautiful, they married any of them they chose.

3.verse: The LORD said, “My Spirit will not remain in human beings forever, because they are flesh. They will live only 120 years.”

4.verse: The Nephilim were on the earth in those days and also later. That was when the sons of God had sexual relations with the daughters of human beings. These women gave birth to children, who became famous and were the mighty warriors of long ago.

5.verse: The LORD saw that the human beings on the earth were very wicked and that everything they thought about was evil.

6.verse: He was sorry he had made human beings on the earth, and his heart was filled with pain.

7.verse: So the LORD said, “I will destroy all human beings that I made on the earth. And I will destroy every animal and everything that crawls on the earth and the birds of the air, because I am sorry I have made them.”

8.verse: But Noah pleased the LORD.

9.verse: Noah and the Great Flood - This is the family history of Noah. Noah was a good man, the most innocent man of his time, and he walked with God.

10.verse: He had three sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth.

11.verse: People on earth did what God said was evil, and violence was everywhere.

12.verse: When God saw that everyone on the earth did only evil,

13.verse: he said to Noah, “Because people have made the earth full of violence, I will destroy all of them from the earth.

14.verse: Build a boat of cypress wood for yourself. Make rooms in it and cover it inside and outside with tar.

15.verse: This is how big I want you to build the boat: four hundred fifty feet long, seventy-five feet wide, and forty-five feet high.

16.verse: Make an opening around the top of the boat that is eighteen inches high from the edge of the roof down. Put a door in the side of the boat. Make an upper, middle, and lower deck in it.

17.verse: I will bring a flood of water on the earth to destroy all living things that live under the sky, including everything that has the breath of life. Everything on the earth will die.

18.verse: But I will make an agreement with you—you, your sons, your wife, and your sons’ wives will all go into the boat.

19.verse: Also, you must bring into the boat two of every living thing, male and female. Keep them alive with you.

20.verse: Two of every kind of bird, animal, and crawling thing will come to you to be kept alive.

21.verse: Also gather some of every kind of food and store it on the boat as food for you and the animals.”

22.verse: Noah did everything that God commanded him.

1.verse: The Flood Begins - Then the LORD said to Noah, “I have seen that you are the best person among the people of this time, so you and your family can go into the boat.

2.verse: Take with you seven pairs, each male with its female, of every kind of clean animal, and take one pair, each male with its female, of every kind of unclean animal.

3.verse: Take seven pairs of all the birds of the sky, each male with its female. This will allow all these animals to continue living on the earth after the flood.

4.verse: Seven days from now I will send rain on the earth. It will rain forty days and forty nights, and I will wipe off from the earth every living thing that I have made.”

5.verse: Noah did everything the LORD commanded him.

6.verse: Noah was six hundred years old when the flood came.

7.verse: He and his wife and his sons and their wives went into the boat to escape the waters of the flood.

8.verse: The clean animals, the unclean animals, the birds, and everything that crawls on the ground

9.verse: came to Noah. They went into the boat in groups of two, male and female, just as God had commanded Noah.

10.verse: Seven days later the flood started.

11.verse: When Noah was six hundred years old, the flood started. On the seventeenth day of the second month of that year the underground springs split open, and the clouds in the sky poured out rain.

12.verse: The rain fell on the earth for forty days and forty nights.

13.verse: On that same day Noah and his wife, his sons Shem, Ham, and Japheth, and their wives went into the boat.

14.verse: They had every kind of wild and tame animal, every kind of animal that crawls on the earth, and every kind of bird.

15.verse: Every creature that had the breath of life came to Noah in the boat in groups of two.

16.verse: One male and one female of every living thing came, just as God had commanded Noah. Then the LORD closed the door behind them.

17.verse: Water flooded the earth for forty days, and as it rose it lifted the boat off the ground.

18.verse: The water continued to rise, and the boat floated on it above the earth.

19.verse: The water rose so much that even the highest mountains under the sky were covered by it.

20.verse: It continued to rise until it was more than twenty feet above the mountains.

21.verse: All living things that moved on the earth died. This included all the birds, tame animals, wild animals, and creatures that swarm on the earth, as well as all human beings.

22.verse: So everything on dry land that had the breath of life in it died.

23.verse: God destroyed from the earth every living thing that was on the land—every man, animal, crawling thing, and bird of the sky. All that was left was Noah and what was with him in the boat.

24.verse: And the waters continued to cover the earth for one hundred fifty days.

1.verse: The Flood Ends - But God remembered Noah and all the wild and tame animals with him in the boat. He made a wind blow over the earth, and the water went down.

2.verse: The underground springs stopped flowing, and the clouds in the sky stopped pouring down rain.

3.verse: The water that covered the earth began to go down. After one hundred fifty days it had gone down so much that the boat touched land again. It came to rest on one of the mountains of Ararat on the seventeenth day of the seventh month.

4.verse: The water that covered the earth began to go down. After one hundred fifty days it had gone down so much that the boat touched land again. It came to rest on one of the mountains of Ararat on the seventeenth day of the seventh month.

5.verse: The water continued to go down so that by the first day of the tenth month the tops of the mountains could be seen.

6.verse: Forty days later Noah opened the window he had made in the boat, and

7.verse: he sent out a raven. It flew here and there until the water had dried up from the earth.

8.verse: Then Noah sent out a dove to find out if the water had dried up from the ground.

9.verse: The dove could not find a place to land because water still covered the earth, so it came back to the boat. Noah reached out his hand and took the bird and brought it back into the boat.

10.verse: After seven days Noah again sent out the dove from the boat,

11.verse: and that evening it came back to him with a fresh olive leaf in its mouth. Then Noah knew that the ground was almost dry.

12.verse: Seven days later he sent the dove out again, but this time it did not come back.

13.verse: When Noah was six hundred and one years old, in the first day of the first month of that year, the water was dried up from the land. Noah removed the covering of the boat and saw that the land was dry.

14.verse: By the twenty-seventh day of the second month the land was completely dry.

15.verse: Then God said to Noah,

16.verse: “You and your wife, your sons, and their wives should go out of the boat.

17.verse: Bring every animal out of the boat with you—the birds, animals, and everything that crawls on the earth. Let them have many young ones so that they might grow in number.”

18.verse: So Noah went out with his sons, his wife, and his sons’ wives.

19.verse: Every animal, everything that crawls on the earth, and every bird went out of the boat by families.

20.verse: Then Noah built an altar to the LORD. He took some of all the clean birds and animals, and he burned them on the altar as offerings to God.

21.verse: The LORD was pleased with these sacrifices and said to himself, “I will never again curse the ground because of human beings. Their thoughts are evil even when they are young, but I will never again destroy every living thing on the earth as I did this time.

22.verse: “As long as the earth continues, planting and harvest, cold and hot, summer and winter, day and night will not stop.”

1.verse: The New Beginning - Then God blessed Noah and his sons and said to them, “Have many children; grow in number and fill the earth.

2.verse: Every animal on earth, every bird in the sky, every animal that crawls on the ground, and every fish in the sea will respect and fear you. I have given them to you.

3.verse: “Everything that moves, everything that is alive, is yours for food. Earlier I gave you the green plants, but now I give you everything for food.

4.verse: But you must not eat meat that still has blood in it, because blood gives life.

5.verse: I will demand blood for life. I will demand the life of any animal that kills a person, and I will demand the life of anyone who takes another person’s life.

6.verse: “Whoever kills a human being will be killed by a human being, because God made humans in his own image.

7.verse: “As for you, Noah, I want you and your family to have many children, to grow in number on the earth, and to become many.”

8.verse: Then God said to Noah and his sons,

9.verse: “Now I am making my agreement with you and your people who will live after you,

10.verse: and with every living thing that is with you—the birds, the tame and the wild animals, and with everything that came out of the boat with you—with every living thing on earth.

11.verse: I make this agreement with you: I will never again destroy all living things by a flood. A flood will never again destroy the earth.”

12.verse: And God said, “This is the sign of the agreement between me and you and every living creature that is with you.

13.verse: I am putting my rainbow in the clouds as the sign of the agreement between me and the earth.

14.verse: When I bring clouds over the earth and a rainbow appears in them,

15.verse: I will remember my agreement between me and you and every living thing. Floods will never again destroy all life on the earth.

16.verse: When the rainbow appears in the clouds, I will see it and I will remember the agreement that continues forever between me and every living thing on the earth.”

17.verse: So God said to Noah, “The rainbow is a sign of the agreement that I made with all living things on earth.”

18.verse: Noah and His Sons - The sons of Noah who came out of the boat with him were Shem, Ham, and Japheth. (Ham was the father of Canaan.)

19.verse: These three men were Noah’s sons, and all the people on earth came from these three sons.

20.verse: Noah became a farmer and planted a vineyard.

21.verse: When he drank wine made from his grapes, he became drunk and lay naked in his tent.

22.verse: Ham, the father of Canaan, looked at his naked father and told his brothers outside.

23.verse: Then Shem and Japheth got a coat and, carrying it on both their shoulders, they walked backwards into the tent and covered their father. They turned their faces away so that they did not see their father’s nakedness.

24.verse: Noah was sleeping because of the wine. When he woke up and learned what his youngest son, Ham, had done to him,

25.verse: he said, “May there be a curse on Canaan! May he be the lowest slave to his brothers.”

26.verse: Noah also said, “May the LORD, the God of Shem, be praised! May Canaan be Shem’s slave.

27.verse: May God give more land to Japheth. May Japheth live in Shem’s tents, and may Canaan be their slave.”

28.verse: After the flood Noah lived 350 years.

29.verse: He lived a total of 950 years, and then he died.

1.verse: Nations Grow and Spread - This is the family history of Shem, Ham, and Japheth, the sons of Noah. After the flood these three men had sons.

2.verse: Japheth’s Sons - The sons of Japheth were Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.

3.verse: The sons of Gomer were Ashkenaz, Riphath, and Togarmah.

4.verse: The sons of Javan were Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim, and Rodanim.

5.verse: Those who lived in the lands around the Mediterranean Sea came from these sons of Japheth. All the families grew and became different nations, each nation with its own land and its own language.

6.verse: Ham’s Sons - The sons of Ham were Cush, Mizraim, Put, and Canaan.

7.verse: The sons of Cush were Seba, Havilah, Sabtah, Raamah, and Sabteca. The sons of Raamah were Sheba and Dedan.

8.verse: Cush also had a descendant named Nimrod, who became a very powerful man on earth.

9.verse: He was a great hunter before the LORD, which is why people say someone is “like Nimrod, a great hunter before the LORD.”

10.verse: At first Nimrod’s kingdom covered Babylon, Erech, Akkad, and Calneh in the land of Babylonia.

11.verse: From there he went to Assyria, where he built the cities of Nineveh, Rehoboth Ir, and Calah.

12.verse: He also built Resen, the great city between Nineveh and Calah.

13.verse: Mizraim was the father of the Ludites, Anamites, Lehabites, Naphtuhites,

14.verse: Pathrusites, Casluhites, and the people of Crete. (The Philistines came from the Casluhites.)

15.verse: Canaan was the father of Sidon, his first son, and of Heth.

16.verse: He was also the father of the Jebusites, Amorites, Girgashites,

17.verse: Hivites, Arkites, Sinites,

18.verse: Arvadites, Zemarites, and Hamathites. The families of the Canaanites scattered.

19.verse: Their land reached from Sidon to Gerar as far as Gaza, and then to Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, and Zeboiim, as far as Lasha.

20.verse: All these people were the sons of Ham, and all these families had their own languages, their own lands, and their own nations.

21.verse: Shem’s Sons - Shem, Japheth’s older brother, also had sons. One of his descendants was the father of all the sons of Eber.

22.verse: The sons of Shem were Elam, Asshur, Arphaxad, Lud, and Aram.

23.verse: The sons of Aram were Uz, Hul, Gether, and Meshech.

24.verse: Arphaxad was the father of Shelah, who was the father of Eber.

25.verse: Eber was the father of two sons—one named Peleg, because the earth was divided during his life, and the other was named Joktan.

26.verse: Joktan was the father of Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,

27.verse: Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah,

28.verse: Obal, Abimael, Sheba,

29.verse: Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab. All these people were the sons of Joktan.

30.verse: They lived in the area between Mesha and Sephar in the hill country in the East.

31.verse: These are the people from the family of Shem, arranged by families, languages, countries, and nations.

32.verse: This is the list of the families from the sons of Noah, arranged according to their nations. From these families came all the nations who spread across the earth after the flood.

1.verse: The Languages Confused - At this time the whole world spoke one language, and everyone used the same words.

2.verse: As people moved from the east, they found a plain in the land of Babylonia and settled there.

3.verse: They said to each other, “Let’s make bricks and bake them to make them hard.” So they used bricks instead of stones, and tar instead of mortar.

4.verse: Then they said to each other, “Let’s build a city and a tower for ourselves, whose top will reach high into the sky. We will become famous. Then we will not be scattered over all the earth.”

5.verse: The LORD came down to see the city and the tower that the people had built.

6.verse: The LORD said, “Now, these people are united, all speaking the same language. This is only the beginning of what they will do. They will be able to do anything they want.

7.verse: Come, let us go down and confuse their language so they will not be able to understand each other.”

8.verse: So the LORD scattered them from there over all the earth, and they stopped building the city.

9.verse: The place is called Babel since that is where the LORD confused the language of the whole world. So the LORD caused them to spread out from there over the whole world.

10.verse: The Story of Shem’s Family - This is the family history of Shem. Two years after the flood, when Shem was 100 years old, his son Arphaxad was born.

11.verse: After that, Shem lived 500 years and had other sons and daughters.

12.verse: When Arphaxad was 35 years old, his son Shelah was born.

13.verse: After that, Arphaxad lived 403 years and had other sons and daughters.

14.verse: When Shelah was 30 years old, his son Eber was born.

15.verse: After that, Shelah lived 403 years and had other sons and daughters.

16.verse: When Eber was 34 years old, his son Peleg was born.

17.verse: After that, Eber lived 430 years and had other sons and daughters.

18.verse: When Peleg was 30 years old, his son Reu was born.

19.verse: After that, Peleg lived 209 years and had other sons and daughters.

20.verse: When Reu was 32 years old, his son Serug was born.

21.verse: After that, Reu lived 207 years and had other sons and daughters.

22.verse: When Serug was 30 years old, his son Nahor was born.

23.verse: After that, Serug lived 200 years and had other sons and daughters.

24.verse: When Nahor was 29 years old, his son Terah was born.

25.verse: After that, Nahor lived 119 years and had other sons and daughters.

26.verse: After Terah was 70 years old, his sons Abram, Nahor, and Haran were born.

27.verse: The Story of Terah’s Family - This is the family history of Terah. Terah was the father of Abram, Nahor, and Haran. Haran was the father of Lot.

28.verse: While his father, Terah, was still alive, Haran died in Ur in Babylonia, where he was born.

29.verse: Abram and Nahor both married. Abram’s wife was named Sarai, and Nahor’s wife was named Milcah. She was the daughter of Haran, who was the father of both Milcah and Iscah.

30.verse: Sarai was not able to have children.

31.verse: Terah took his son Abram, his grandson Lot (Haran’s son), and his daughter-in-law Sarai (Abram’s wife) and moved out of Ur of Babylonia. They had planned to go to the land of Canaan, but when they reached the city of Haran, they settled there.

32.verse: Terah lived to be 205 years old, and then he died in Haran.

1.verse: God Calls Abram - The LORD said to Abram, “Leave your country, your relatives, and your father’s family, and go to the land I will show you.

2.verse: I will make you a great nation, and I will bless you. I will make you famous, and you will be a blessing to others.

3.verse: I will bless those who bless you, and I will place a curse on those who harm you. And all the people on earth will be blessed through you.”

4.verse: So Abram left Haran as the LORD had told him, and Lot went with him. At this time Abram was 75 years old.

5.verse: He took his wife Sarai, his nephew Lot, and everything they owned, as well as all the servants they had gotten in Haran. They set out from Haran, planning to go to the land of Canaan, and in time they arrived there.

6.verse: Abram traveled through that land as far as the great tree of Moreh at Shechem. The Canaanites were living in the land at that time.

7.verse: The LORD appeared to Abram and said, “I will give this land to your descendants.” So Abram built an altar there to the LORD, who had appeared to him.

8.verse: Then he traveled from Shechem to the mountain east of Bethel and set up his tent there. Bethel was to the west, and Ai was to the east. There Abram built another altar to the LORD and worshiped him.

9.verse: After this, he traveled on toward southern Canaan.

10.verse: Abram Goes to Egypt - At this time there was not much food in the land, so Abram went down to Egypt to live because there was so little food.

11.verse: Just before they arrived in Egypt, he said to his wife Sarai, “I know you are a very beautiful woman.

12.verse: When the Egyptians see you, they will say, ‘This woman is his wife.’ Then they will kill me but let you live.

13.verse: Tell them you are my sister so that things will go well with me and I may be allowed to live because of you.”

14.verse: When Abram came to Egypt, the Egyptians saw that Sarai was very beautiful.

15.verse: The Egyptian officers saw her and told the king of Egypt how beautiful she was. They took her to the king’s palace, and

16.verse: the king was kind to Abram because he thought Abram was her brother. He gave Abram sheep, cattle, male and female donkeys, male and female servants, and camels.

17.verse: But the LORD sent terrible diseases on the king and all the people in his house because of Abram’s wife Sarai.

18.verse: So the king sent for Abram and said, “What have you done to me? Why didn’t you tell me Sarai was your wife?

19.verse: Why did you say, ‘She is my sister’ so that I made her my wife? Now, here is your wife. Take her and leave!”

20.verse: Then the king commanded his men to make Abram leave Egypt; so Abram and his wife left with everything they owned.

1.verse: Abram and Lot Separate - So Abram, his wife, and Lot left Egypt, taking everything they owned, and traveled to southern Canaan.

2.verse: Abram was very rich in cattle, silver, and gold.

3.verse: He left southern Canaan and went back to Bethel where he had camped before, between Bethel and Ai,

4.verse: and where he had built an altar. So he worshiped the LORD there.

5.verse: During this time Lot was traveling with Abram, and Lot also had flocks, herds, and tents.

6.verse: Abram and Lot had so many animals that the land could not support both of them together,

7.verse: so Abram’s herdsmen and Lot’s herdsmen began to argue. The Canaanites and the Perizzites were living in the land at this time.

8.verse: Abram said to Lot, “There should be no arguing between you and me, or between your herdsmen and mine, because we are brothers.

9.verse: We should separate. The whole land is there in front of you. If you go to the left, I will go to the right. If you go to the right, I will go to the left.”

10.verse: Lot looked all around and saw the whole Jordan Valley and that there was much water there. It was like the LORD’s garden, like the land of Egypt in the direction of Zoar. (This was before the LORD destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah.)

11.verse: So Lot chose to move east and live in the Jordan Valley. In this way Abram and Lot separated.

12.verse: Abram lived in the land of Canaan, but Lot lived among the cities in the Jordan Valley, very near to Sodom.

13.verse: Now the people of Sodom were very evil and were always sinning against the LORD.

14.verse: After Lot left, the LORD said to Abram, “Look all around you—to the north and south and east and west.

15.verse: All this land that you see I will give to you and your descendants forever.

16.verse: I will make your descendants as many as the dust of the earth. If anyone could count the dust on the earth, he could count your people.

17.verse: Get up! Walk through all this land because I am now giving it to you.”

18.verse: So Abram moved his tents and went to live near the great trees of Mamre at the city of Hebron. There he built an altar to the LORD.

1.verse: Lot Is Captured - Now Amraphel was king of Babylonia, Arioch was king of Ellasar, Kedorlaomer was king of Elam, and Tidal was king of Goiim.

2.verse: All these kings went to war against several other kings: Bera king of Sodom, Birsha king of Gomorrah, Shinab king of Admah, Shemeber king of Zeboiim, and the king of Bela. (Bela is also called Zoar.)

3.verse: These kings who were attacked united their armies in the Valley of Siddim (now the Dead Sea).

4.verse: They had served Kedorlaomer for twelve years, but in the thirteenth year, they all turned against him.

5.verse: Then in the fourteenth year, Kedorlaomer and the kings with him came and defeated the Rephaites in Ashteroth Karnaim, the Zuzites in Ham, and the Emites in Shaveh Kiriathaim.

6.verse: They also defeated the Horites in the mountains of Edom to El Paran (near the desert).

7.verse: Then they turned back and went to En Mishpat (that is, Kadesh). They defeated all the Amalekites, as well as the Amorites who lived in Hazazon Tamar.

8.verse: At that time the kings of Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, Zeboiim, and Bela went out to fight in the Valley of Siddim. (Bela is called Zoar.)

9.verse: They fought against Kedorlaomer king of Elam, Tidal king of Goiim, Amraphel king of Babylonia, and Arioch king of Ellasar—four kings fighting against five.

10.verse: There were many tar pits in the Valley of Siddim. When the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah and their armies ran away, some of the soldiers fell into the tar pits, but the others ran away to the mountains.

11.verse: Now Kedorlaomer and his armies took everything the people of Sodom and Gomorrah owned, including their food.

12.verse: They took Lot, Abram’s nephew who was living in Sodom, and everything he owned. Then they left.

13.verse: One of the men who was not captured went to Abram, the Hebrew, and told him what had happened. At that time Abram was camped near the great trees of Mamre the Amorite. Mamre was a brother of Eshcol and Aner, and they had all made an agreement to help Abram.

14.verse: Abram Rescues Lot - When Abram learned that Lot had been captured, he called out his 318 trained men who had been born in his camp. He led the men and chased the enemy all the way to the town of Dan.

15.verse: That night he divided his men into groups, and they made a surprise attack against the enemy. They chased them all the way to Hobah, north of Damascus.

16.verse: Then Abram brought back everything the enemy had stolen, the women and the other people, and Lot, and everything Lot owned.

17.verse: After defeating Kedorlaomer and the kings who were with him, Abram went home. As he was returning, the king of Sodom came out to meet him in the Valley of Shaveh (now called King’s Valley).

18.verse: Melchizedek king of Salem brought out bread and wine. He was a priest for God Most High

19.verse: and blessed Abram, saying, “Abram, may you be blessed by God Most High, the God who made heaven and earth.

20.verse: And we praise God Most High, who has helped you to defeat your enemies.” Then Abram gave Melchizedek a tenth of everything he had brought back from the battle.

21.verse: The king of Sodom said to Abram, “You may keep all these things for yourself. Just give me my people who were captured.”

22.verse: But Abram said to the king of Sodom, “I make a promise to the LORD, the God Most High, who made heaven and earth.

23.verse: I promise that I will not keep anything that is yours. I will not keep even a thread or a sandal strap so that you cannot say, ‘I made Abram rich.’

24.verse: I will keep nothing but the food my young men have eaten. But give Aner, Eshcol, and Mamre their share of what we won, because they went with me into battle.”

1.verse: God’s Agreement with Abram - After these things happened, the LORD spoke his word to Abram in a vision: “Abram, don’t be afraid. I will defend you, and I will give you a great reward.”

2.verse: But Abram said, “Lord GOD, what can you give me? I have no son, so my slave Eliezer from Damascus will get everything I own after I die.”

3.verse: Abram said, “Look, you have given me no son, so a slave born in my house will inherit everything I have.”

4.verse: Then the LORD spoke his word to Abram: “He will not be the one to inherit what you have. You will have a son of your own who will inherit what you have.”

5.verse: Then God led Abram outside and said, “Look at the sky. There are so many stars you cannot count them. Your descendants also will be too many to count.”

6.verse: Abram believed the LORD. And the LORD accepted Abram’s faith, and that faith made him right with God.

7.verse: God said to Abram, “I am the LORD who led you out of Ur of Babylonia so that I could give you this land to own.”

8.verse: But Abram said, “Lord GOD, how can I be sure that I will own this land?”

9.verse: The LORD said to Abram, “Bring me a three-year-old cow, a three-year-old goat, a three-year-old male sheep, a dove, and a young pigeon.”

10.verse: Abram brought them all to God. Then Abram killed the animals and cut each of them into two pieces, laying each half opposite the other half. But he did not cut the birds in half.

11.verse: Later, large birds flew down to eat the animals, but Abram chased them away.

12.verse: As the sun was going down, Abram fell into a deep sleep. While he was asleep, a very terrible darkness came.

13.verse: Then the LORD said to Abram, “You can be sure that your descendants will be strangers and travel in a land they don’t own. The people there will make them slaves and be cruel to them for four hundred years.

14.verse: But I will punish the nation where they are slaves. Then your descendants will leave that land, taking great wealth with them.

15.verse: And you, Abram, will die in peace and will be buried at an old age.

16.verse: After your great-great-grandchildren are born, your people will come to this land again. It will take that long, because I am not yet going to punish the Amorites for their evil behavior.”

17.verse: After the sun went down, it was very dark. Suddenly a smoking firepot and a blazing torch passed between the halves of the dead animals.

18.verse: So on that day the LORD made an agreement with Abram and said, “I will give to your descendants the land between the river of Egypt and the great river Euphrates.

19.verse: This is the land of the Kenites, Kenizzites, Kadmonites,

20.verse: Hittites, Perizzites, Rephaites,

21.verse: Amorites, Canaanites, Girgashites, and Jebusites.”

1.verse: Ishmael Is Born - Sarai, Abram’s wife, had no children, but she had a slave girl from Egypt named Hagar.

2.verse: Sarai said to Abram, “Look, the LORD has not allowed me to have children, so have sexual relations with my slave girl. If she has a child, maybe I can have my own family through her.” Abram did what Sarai said.

3.verse: It was after he had lived ten years in Canaan that Sarai gave Hagar to her husband Abram. (Hagar was her slave girl from Egypt.)

4.verse: Abram had sexual relations with Hagar, and she became pregnant. When Hagar learned she was pregnant, she began to treat her mistress Sarai badly.

5.verse: Then Sarai said to Abram, “This is your fault. I gave my slave girl to you, and when she became pregnant, she began to treat me badly. Let the LORD decide who is right—you or me.”

6.verse: But Abram said to Sarai, “You are Hagar’s mistress. Do anything you want to her.” Then Sarai was hard on Hagar, and Hagar ran away.

7.verse: The angel of the LORD found Hagar beside a spring of water in the desert, by the road to Shur.

8.verse: The angel said, “Hagar, Sarai’s slave girl, where have you come from? Where are you going?” Hagar answered, “I am running away from my mistress Sarai.”

9.verse: The angel of the LORD said to her, “Go home to your mistress and obey her.”

10.verse: The angel also said, “I will give you so many descendants they cannot be counted.”

11.verse: The angel added, “You are now pregnant, and you will have a son. You will name him Ishmael, because the LORD has heard your cries.

12.verse: Ishmael will be like a wild donkey. He will be against everyone, and everyone will be against him. He will attack all his brothers.”

13.verse: The slave girl gave a name to the LORD who spoke to her: “You are ‘God who sees me,’” because she said to herself, “Have I really seen God who sees me?”

14.verse: So the well there, between Kadesh and Bered, was called Beer Lahai Roi.

15.verse: Hagar gave birth to a son for Abram, and Abram named him Ishmael.

16.verse: Abram was eighty-six years old when Hagar gave birth to Ishmael.

1.verse: Proof of the Agreement - When Abram was ninety-nine years old, the LORD appeared to him and said, “I am God Almighty. Obey me and do what is right.

2.verse: I will make an agreement between us, and I will make you the ancestor of many people.”

3.verse: Then Abram bowed facedown on the ground. God said to him,

4.verse: “I am making my agreement with you: I will make you the father of many nations.

5.verse: I am changing your name from Abram to Abraham because I am making you a father of many nations.

6.verse: I will give you many descendants. New nations will be born from you, and kings will come from you.

7.verse: And I will make an agreement between me and you and all your descendants from now on: I will be your God and the God of all your descendants.

8.verse: You live in the land of Canaan now as a stranger, but I will give you and your descendants all this land forever. And I will be the God of your descendants.”

9.verse: Then God said to Abraham, “You and your descendants must keep this agreement from now on.

10.verse: This is my agreement with you and all your descendants, which you must obey: Every male among you must be circumcised.

11.verse: Cut away your foreskin to show that you are prepared to follow the agreement between me and you.

12.verse: From now on when a baby boy is eight days old, you will circumcise him. This includes any boy born among your people or any who is your slave, who is not one of your descendants.

13.verse: Circumcise every baby boy whether he is born in your family or bought as a slave. Your bodies will be marked to show that you are part of my agreement that lasts forever.

14.verse: Any male who is not circumcised will be cut off from his people, because he has broken my agreement.”

15.verse: Isaac—the Promised Son - God said to Abraham, “I will change the name of Sarai, your wife, to Sarah.

16.verse: I will bless her and give her a son, and you will be the father. She will be the mother of many nations. Kings of nations will come from her.”

17.verse: Abraham bowed facedown on the ground and laughed. He said to himself, “Can a man have a child when he is a hundred years old? Can Sarah give birth to a child when she is ninety?”

18.verse: Then Abraham said to God, “Please let Ishmael be the son you promised.”

19.verse: God said, “No, Sarah your wife will have a son, and you will name him Isaac. I will make my agreement with him to be an agreement that continues forever with all his descendants.

20.verse: “As for Ishmael, I have heard you. I will bless him and give him many descendants. And I will cause their numbers to grow greatly. He will be the father of twelve great leaders, and I will make him into a great nation.

21.verse: But I will make my agreement with Isaac, the son whom Sarah will have at this same time next year.”

22.verse: After God finished talking with Abraham, God rose and left him.

23.verse: Then Abraham gathered Ishmael, all the males born in his camp, and the slaves he had bought. So that day Abraham circumcised every man and boy in his camp as God had told him to do.

24.verse: Abraham was ninety-nine years old when he was circumcised.

25.verse: And Ishmael, his son, was thirteen years old when he was circumcised.

26.verse: Abraham and his son were circumcised on the same day.

27.verse: Also on that day all the men in Abraham’s camp were circumcised, including all those born in his camp and all the slaves he had bought from other nations.

1.verse: The Three Visitors - Later, the LORD again appeared to Abraham near the great trees of Mamre. Abraham was sitting at the entrance of his tent during the hottest part of the day.

2.verse: He looked up and saw three men standing near him. When Abraham saw them, he ran from his tent to meet them. He bowed facedown on the ground before them

3.verse: and said, “Sir, if you think well of me, please stay awhile with me, your servant.

4.verse: I will bring some water so all of you can wash your feet. You may rest under the tree,

5.verse: and I will get some bread for you so you can regain your strength. Then you may continue your journey.” The three men said, “That is fine. Do as you said.”

6.verse: Abraham hurried to the tent where Sarah was and said to her, “Hurry, prepare twenty quarts of fine flour, and make it into loaves of bread.”

7.verse: Then Abraham ran to his herd and took one of his best calves. He gave it to a servant, who hurried to kill it and to prepare it for food.

8.verse: Abraham gave the three men the calf that had been cooked and milk curds and milk. While they ate, he stood under the tree near them.

9.verse: The men asked Abraham, “Where is your wife Sarah?” “There, in the tent,” said Abraham.

10.verse: Then the LORD said, “I will certainly return to you about this time a year from now. At that time your wife Sarah will have a son.” Sarah was listening at the entrance of the tent which was behind him.

11.verse: Abraham and Sarah were very old. Since Sarah was past the age when women normally have children,

12.verse: she laughed to herself, “My husband and I are too old to have a baby.”

13.verse: Then the LORD said to Abraham, “Why did Sarah laugh? Why did she say, ‘I am too old to have a baby’?

14.verse: Is anything too hard for the LORD? No! I will return to you at the right time a year from now, and Sarah will have a son.”

15.verse: Sarah was afraid, so she lied and said, “I didn’t laugh.” But the LORD said, “No. You did laugh.”

16.verse: Then the men got up to leave and started out toward Sodom. Abraham walked along with them a short time to send them on their way.

17.verse: Abraham’s Bargain with God - The LORD said, “Should I tell Abraham what I am going to do now?

18.verse: Abraham’s children will certainly become a great and powerful nation, and all nations on earth will be blessed through him.

19.verse: I have chosen him so he would command his children and his descendants to live the way the LORD wants them to, to live right and be fair. Then I, the LORD, will give Abraham what I promised him.”

20.verse: Then the LORD said, “I have heard many complaints against the people of Sodom and Gomorrah. They are very evil.

21.verse: I will go down and see if they are as bad as I have heard. If not, I will know.”

22.verse: So the men turned and went toward Sodom, but Abraham stood there before the LORD.

23.verse: Then Abraham approached him and asked, “Do you plan to destroy the good people along with the evil ones?

24.verse: What if there are fifty good people in that city? Will you still destroy it? Surely you will save the city for the fifty good people living there.

25.verse: Surely you will not destroy the good people along with the evil ones; then they would be treated the same. You are the judge of all the earth. Won’t you do what is right?”

26.verse: The LORD said, “If I find fifty good people in the city of Sodom, I will save the whole city because of them.”

27.verse: Then Abraham said, “Though I am only dust and ashes, I have been brave to speak to the Lord.

28.verse: What if there are only forty-five good people in the city? Will you destroy the whole city for the lack of five good people?” The LORD said, “If I find forty-five there, I will not destroy the city.”

29.verse: Again Abraham said to him, “If you find only forty good people there, will you destroy the city?” The LORD said, “If I find forty, I will not destroy it.”

30.verse: Then Abraham said, “Lord, please don’t be angry with me, but let me ask you this. If you find only thirty good people in the city, will you destroy it?” He said, “If I find thirty good people there, I will not destroy the city.”

31.verse: Then Abraham said, “I have been brave to speak to the Lord. But what if there are twenty good people in the city?” He answered, “If I find twenty there, I will not destroy the city.”

32.verse: Then Abraham said, “Lord, please don’t be angry with me, but let me bother you this one last time. What if you find ten there?” He said, “If I find ten there, I will not destroy it.”

33.verse: When the LORD finished speaking to Abraham, he left, and Abraham returned home.

1.verse: Lot Leaves Sodom - The two angels came to Sodom in the evening as Lot was sitting near the city gate. When he saw them, he got up and went to them and bowed facedown on the ground.

2.verse: Lot said, “Sirs, please come to my house and spend the night. There you can wash your feet, and then tomorrow you may continue your journey.” The angels answered, “No, we will spend the night in the city’s public square.”

3.verse: But Lot begged them to come, so they agreed and went to his house. Then Lot prepared a meal for them. He baked bread without yeast, and they ate it.

4.verse: Before bedtime, men both young and old and from every part of Sodom surrounded Lot’s house.

5.verse: They called to Lot, “Where are the two men who came to you tonight? Bring them out to us so we can have sexual relations with them.”

6.verse: Lot went outside to them, closing the door behind him.

7.verse: He said, “No, my brothers! Do not do this evil thing.

8.verse: Look! I have two daughters who have never slept with a man. I will give them to you, and you may do anything you want with them. But please don’t do anything to these men. They have come to my house, and I must protect them.”

9.verse: The men around the house answered, “Move out of the way!” Then they said to each other, “This man Lot came to our city as a stranger, and now he wants to tell us what to do!” They said to Lot, “We will do worse things to you than to them.” They started pushing him back and were ready to break down the door.

10.verse: But the two men staying with Lot opened the door, pulled him back inside the house, and then closed the door.

11.verse: They struck those outside the door with blindness, so the men, both young and old, could not find the door.

12.verse: The two men said to Lot, “Do you have any other relatives in this city? Do you have any sons-in-law, sons, daughters, or any other relatives? If you do, tell them to leave now,

13.verse: because we are about to destroy this city. The LORD has heard of all the evil that is here, so he has sent us to destroy it.”

14.verse: So Lot went out and said to his future sons-in-law who were pledged to marry his daughters, “Hurry and leave this city! The LORD is about to destroy it!” But they thought Lot was joking.

15.verse: At dawn the next morning, the angels begged Lot to hurry. They said, “Go! Take your wife and your two daughters with you so you will not be destroyed when the city is punished.”

16.verse: But Lot delayed. So the two men took the hands of Lot, his wife, and his two daughters and led them safely out of the city. So the LORD was merciful to Lot and his family.

17.verse: After they brought them out of the city, one of the men said, “Run for your lives! Don’t look back or stop anywhere in the valley. Run to the mountains, or you will be destroyed.”

18.verse: But Lot said to one of them, “Sir, please don’t force me to go so far!

19.verse: You have been merciful and kind to me and have saved my life. But I can’t run to the mountains. The disaster will catch me, and I will die.

20.verse: Look, that little town over there is not too far away. Let me run there. It’s really just a little town, and I’ll be safe there.”

21.verse: The angel said to Lot, “Very well, I will allow you to do this also. I will not destroy that town.

22.verse: But run there fast, because I cannot destroy Sodom until you are safely in that town.” (That town is named Zoar, because it is little.)

23.verse: Sodom and Gomorrah Are Destroyed - The sun had already come up when Lot entered Zoar.

24.verse: The LORD sent a rain of burning sulfur down from the sky on Sodom and Gomorrah

25.verse: and destroyed those cities. He also destroyed the whole Jordan Valley, everyone living in the cities, and even all the plants.

26.verse: At that point Lot’s wife looked back. When she did, she became a pillar of salt.

27.verse: Early the next morning, Abraham got up and went to the place where he had stood before the LORD.

28.verse: He looked down toward Sodom and Gomorrah and all the Jordan Valley and saw smoke rising from the land, like smoke from a furnace.

29.verse: God destroyed the cities in the valley, but he remembered what Abraham had asked. So God saved Lot’s life, but he destroyed the city where Lot had lived.

30.verse: Lot and His Daughters - Lot was afraid to continue living in Zoar, so he and his two daughters went to live in the mountains in a cave.

31.verse: One day the older daughter said to the younger, “Our father is old. Everywhere on the earth women and men marry, but there are no men around here for us to marry.

32.verse: Let’s get our father drunk and have sexual relations with him. We can use him to have children and continue our family.”

33.verse: That night the two girls got their father drunk, and the older daughter went and had sexual relations with him. But Lot did not know when she lay down or when she got up.

34.verse: The next day the older daughter said to the younger, “Last night I had sexual relations with my father. Let’s get him drunk again tonight so you can go and have sexual relations with him, too. In this way we can use our father to have children to continue our family.”

35.verse: So that night they got their father drunk again, and the younger daughter went and had sexual relations with him. Again, Lot did not know when she lay down or when she got up.

36.verse: So both of Lot’s daughters became pregnant by their father.

37.verse: The older daughter gave birth to a son and named him Moab. He is the ancestor of all the Moabite people who are still living today.

38.verse: The younger daughter also gave birth to a son and named him Ben-Ammi. He is the father of all the Ammonite people who are still living today.

1.verse: Abraham Tricks Abimelech - Abraham left Hebron and traveled to southern Canaan where he stayed awhile between Kadesh and Shur. When he moved to Gerar,

2.verse: he told people that his wife Sarah was his sister. Abimelech king of Gerar heard this, so he sent some servants to take her.

3.verse: But one night God spoke to Abimelech in a dream and said, “You will die. The woman you took is married.”

4.verse: But Abimelech had not gone near Sarah, so he said, “Lord, would you destroy an innocent nation?

5.verse: Abraham himself told me, ‘This woman is my sister,’ and she also said, ‘He is my brother.’ I am innocent. I did not know I was doing anything wrong.”

6.verse: Then God said to Abimelech in the dream, “Yes, I know you did not realize what you were doing. So I did not allow you to sin against me and touch her.

7.verse: Give Abraham his wife back. He is a prophet. He will pray for you, and you will not die. But if you do not give Sarah back, you and all your family will surely die.”

8.verse: So early the next morning, Abimelech called all his officers and told them everything that had happened in the dream. They were very afraid.

9.verse: Then Abimelech called Abraham to him and said, “What have you done to us? What wrong did I do against you? Why did you bring this trouble to my kingdom? You should not have done these things to me.

10.verse: What were you thinking that caused you to do this?”

11.verse: Then Abraham answered, “I thought no one in this place respected God and that someone would kill me to get Sarah.

12.verse: And it is true that she is my sister. She is the daughter of my father, but she is not the daughter of my mother.

13.verse: When God told me to leave my father’s house and wander in many different places, I told Sarah, ‘You must do a special favor for me. Everywhere we go tell people I am your brother.’”

14.verse: Then Abimelech gave Abraham some sheep, cattle, and male and female slaves. He also gave Sarah, Abraham’s wife, back to him

15.verse: and said, “Look around you at my land. You may live anywhere you want.”

16.verse: Abimelech said to Sarah, “I gave your brother Abraham twenty-five pounds of silver to make up for any wrong that people may think about you. I want everyone to know that you are innocent.”

17.verse: Then Abraham prayed to God, and God healed Abimelech, his wife, and his servant girls so they could have children.

18.verse: The LORD had kept all the women in Abimelech’s house from having children as a punishment on Abimelech for taking Abraham’s wife Sarah.

1.verse: A Baby for Sarah - The LORD cared for Sarah as he had said and did for her what he had promised.

2.verse: Sarah became pregnant and gave birth to a son for Abraham in his old age. Everything happened at the time God had said it would.

3.verse: Abraham named his son Isaac, the son Sarah gave birth to.

4.verse: He circumcised Isaac when he was eight days old as God had commanded.

5.verse: Abraham was one hundred years old when his son Isaac was born.

6.verse: And Sarah said, “God has made me laugh. Everyone who hears about this will laugh with me.

7.verse: No one thought that I would be able to have Abraham’s child, but even though Abraham is old I have given him a son.”

8.verse: Hagar and Ishmael Leave - Isaac grew, and when he became old enough to eat food, Abraham gave a great feast.

9.verse: But Sarah saw Ishmael making fun of Isaac. (Ishmael was the son of Abraham by Hagar, Sarah’s Egyptian slave.)

10.verse: So Sarah said to Abraham, “Throw out this slave woman and her son. Her son should not inherit anything; my son Isaac should receive it all.”

11.verse: This troubled Abraham very much because Ishmael was also his son.

12.verse: But God said to Abraham, “Don’t be troubled about the boy and the slave woman. Do whatever Sarah tells you. The descendants I promised you will be from Isaac.

13.verse: I will also make the descendants of Ishmael into a great nation because he is your son, too.”

14.verse: Early the next morning Abraham took some food and a leather bag full of water. He gave them to Hagar and sent her away. Carrying these things and her son, Hagar went and wandered in the desert of Beersheba.

15.verse: Later, when all the water was gone from the bag, Hagar put her son under a bush.

16.verse: Then she went away a short distance and sat down. She thought, “My son will die, and I cannot watch this happen.” She sat there and began to cry.

17.verse: God heard the boy crying, and God’s angel called to Hagar from heaven. He said, “What is wrong, Hagar? Don’t be afraid! God has heard the boy crying there.

18.verse: Help him up and take him by the hand. I will make his descendants into a great nation.”

19.verse: Then God showed Hagar a well of water. So she went to the well and filled her bag with water and gave the boy a drink.

20.verse: God was with the boy as he grew up. Ishmael lived in the desert and became an archer.

21.verse: He lived in the Desert of Paran, and his mother found a wife for him in Egypt.

22.verse: Abraham’s Bargain with Abimelech - Then Abimelech came with Phicol, the commander of his army, and said to Abraham, “God is with you in everything you do.

23.verse: So make a promise to me here before God that you will be fair with me and my children and my descendants. Be kind to me and to this land where you have lived as a stranger—as kind as I have been to you.”

24.verse: And Abraham said, “I promise.”

25.verse: Then Abraham complained to Abimelech about Abimelech’s servants who had seized a well of water.

26.verse: But Abimelech said, “I don’t know who did this. You never told me about this before today.”

27.verse: Then Abraham gave Abimelech some sheep and cattle, and they made an agreement.

28.verse: Abraham also put seven female lambs in front of Abimelech.

29.verse: Abimelech asked Abraham, “Why did you put these seven female lambs by themselves?”

30.verse: Abraham answered, “Accept these lambs from me to prove that you believe I dug this well.”

31.verse: So that place was called Beersheba because they made a promise to each other there.

32.verse: After Abraham and Abimelech made the agreement at Beersheba, Abimelech and Phicol, the commander of his army, went back to the land of the Philistines.

33.verse: Abraham planted a tamarisk tree at Beersheba and prayed to the LORD, the God who lives forever.

34.verse: And Abraham lived as a stranger in the land of the Philistines for a long time.

1.verse: God Tests Abraham - After these things God tested Abraham’s faith. God said to him, “Abraham!” And he answered, “Here I am.”

2.verse: Then God said, “Take your only son, Isaac, the son you love, and go to the land of Moriah. Kill him there and offer him as a whole burnt offering on one of the mountains I will tell you about.”

3.verse: Abraham got up early in the morning and saddled his donkey. He took Isaac and two servants with him. After he cut the wood for the sacrifice, they went to the place God had told them to go.

4.verse: On the third day Abraham looked up and saw the place in the distance.

5.verse: He said to his servants, “Stay here with the donkey. My son and I will go over there and worship, and then we will come back to you.”

6.verse: Abraham took the wood for the sacrifice and gave it to his son to carry, but he himself took the knife and the fire. So he and his son went on together.

7.verse: Isaac said to his father Abraham, “Father!” Abraham answered, “Yes, my son.” Isaac said, “We have the fire and the wood, but where is the lamb we will burn as a sacrifice?”

8.verse: Abraham answered, “God will give us the lamb for the sacrifice, my son.” So Abraham and his son went on together

9.verse: and came to the place God had told him about. Abraham built an altar there. He laid the wood on it and then tied up his son Isaac and laid him on the wood on the altar.

10.verse: Then Abraham took his knife and was about to kill his son.

11.verse: But the angel of the LORD called to him from heaven and said, “Abraham! Abraham!” Abraham answered, “Yes.”

12.verse: The angel said, “Don’t kill your son or hurt him in any way. Now I can see that you trust God and that you have not kept your son, your only son, from me.”

13.verse: Then Abraham looked up and saw a male sheep caught in a bush by its horns. So Abraham went and took the sheep and killed it. He offered it as a whole burnt offering to God, and his son was saved.

14.verse: So Abraham named that place The LORD Provides. Even today people say, “On the mountain of the LORD it will be provided.”

15.verse: The angel of the LORD called to Abraham from heaven a second time

16.verse: and said, “The LORD says, ‘Because you did not keep back your son, your only son, from me, I make you this promise by my own name:

17.verse: I will surely bless you and give you many descendants. They will be as many as the stars in the sky and the sand on the seashore, and they will capture the cities of their enemies.

18.verse: Through your descendants all the nations on the earth will be blessed, because you obeyed me.’”

19.verse: Then Abraham returned to his servants. They all traveled back to Beersheba, and Abraham stayed there.

20.verse: After these things happened, someone told Abraham: “Your brother Nahor and his wife Milcah have children now.

21.verse: The first son is Uz, and the second is Buz. The third son is Kemuel (the father of Aram).

22.verse: Then there are Kesed, Hazo, Pildash, Jidlaph, and Bethuel.”

23.verse: Bethuel became the father of Rebekah. Milcah was the mother of these eight sons, and Nahor, Abraham’s brother, was the father.

24.verse: Also Nahor had four other sons by his slave woman Reumah. Their names were Tebah, Gaham, Tahash, and Maacah.

1.verse: Sarah Dies - Sarah lived to be one hundred twenty-seven years old.

2.verse: She died in Kiriath Arba (that is, Hebron) in the land of Canaan. Abraham was very sad and cried because of her.

3.verse: After a while he got up from the side of his wife’s body and went to talk to the Hittites. He said,

4.verse: “I am only a stranger and a foreigner here. Sell me some of your land so that I can bury my dead wife.”

5.verse: The Hittites answered Abraham,

6.verse: “Sir, you are a great leader among us. You may have the best place we have to bury your dead. You may have any of our burying places that you want, and none of us will stop you from burying your dead wife.”

7.verse: Abraham rose and bowed to the people of the land, the Hittites.

8.verse: He said to them, “If you truly want to help me bury my dead wife here, speak to Ephron, the son of Zohar for me.

9.verse: Ask him to sell me the cave of Machpelah at the edge of his field. I will pay him the full price. You can be the witnesses that I am buying it as a burial place.”

10.verse: Ephron was sitting among the Hittites at the city gate. He answered Abraham,

11.verse: “No, sir. I will give you the land and the cave that is in it, with these people as witnesses. Bury your dead wife.”

12.verse: Then Abraham bowed down before the Hittites.

13.verse: He said to Ephron before all the people, “Please let me pay you the full price for the field. Accept my money, and I will bury my dead there.”

14.verse: Ephron answered Abraham,

15.verse: “Sir, the land is worth ten pounds of silver, but I won’t argue with you over the price. Take the land, and bury your dead wife.”

16.verse: Abraham agreed and paid Ephron in front of the Hittite witnesses. He weighed out the full price, ten pounds of silver, and they counted the weight as the traders normally did.

17.verse: So Ephron’s field in Machpelah, east of Mamre, was sold. Abraham became the owner of the field, the cave in it, and all the trees that were in the field. The sale was made at the city gate, with the Hittites as witnesses.

18.verse: So Ephron’s field in Machpelah, east of Mamre, was sold. Abraham became the owner of the field, the cave in it, and all the trees that were in the field. The sale was made at the city gate, with the Hittites as witnesses.

19.verse: After this, Abraham buried his wife Sarah in the cave in the field of Machpelah, near Mamre. (Mamre was later called Hebron in the land of Canaan.)

20.verse: So Abraham bought the field and the cave in it from the Hittites to use as a burying place.

1.verse: A Wife for Isaac - Abraham was now very old, and the LORD had blessed him in every way.

2.verse: Abraham said to his oldest servant, who was in charge of everything he owned, “Put your hand under my leg.

3.verse: Make a promise to me before the LORD, the God of heaven and earth. Don’t get a wife for my son from the Canaanite girls who live around here.

4.verse: Instead, go back to my country, to the land of my relatives, and get a wife for my son Isaac.”

5.verse: The servant said to him, “What if this woman does not want to return with me to this land? Then, should I take your son with me back to your homeland?”

6.verse: Abraham said to him, “No! Don’t take my son back there.

7.verse: The LORD, the God of heaven, brought me from the home of my father and the land of my relatives. And he promised me, ‘I will give this land to your descendants.’ The LORD will send his angel before you to help you get a wife for my son there.

8.verse: If the girl won’t come back with you, you will be free from this promise. But you must not take my son back there.”

9.verse: So the servant put his hand under his master’s leg and made a promise to Abraham about this.

10.verse: The servant took ten of Abraham’s camels and left, carrying with him many different kinds of beautiful gifts. He went to Northwest Mesopotamia to Nahor’s city.

11.verse: In the evening, when the women come out to get water, he made the camels kneel down at the well outside the city.

12.verse: The servant said, “LORD, God of my master Abraham, allow me to find a wife for his son today. Please show this kindness to my master Abraham.

13.verse: Here I am, standing by the spring, and the girls from the city are coming out to get water.

14.verse: I will say to one of them, ‘Please put your jar down so I can drink.’ Then let her say, ‘Drink, and I will also give water to your camels.’ If that happens, I will know she is the right one for your servant Isaac and that you have shown kindness to my master.”

15.verse: Before the servant had finished praying, Rebekah, the daughter of Bethuel, came out of the city. (Bethuel was the son of Milcah and Nahor, Abraham’s brother.) Rebekah was carrying her water jar on her shoulder.

16.verse: She was very pretty, a virgin; she had never had sexual relations with a man. She went down to the spring and filled her jar, then came back up.

17.verse: The servant ran to her and said, “Please give me a little water from your jar.”

18.verse: Rebekah said, “Drink, sir.” She quickly lowered the jar from her shoulder and gave him a drink.

19.verse: After he finished drinking, Rebekah said, “I will also pour some water for your camels.”

20.verse: So she quickly poured all the water from her jar into the drinking trough for the camels. Then she kept running to the well until she had given all the camels enough to drink.

21.verse: The servant quietly watched her. He wanted to be sure the LORD had made his trip successful.

22.verse: After the camels had finished drinking, he gave Rebekah a gold ring weighing one-fifth of an ounce and two gold arm bracelets weighing about four ounces each.

23.verse: He asked, “Who is your father? Is there a place in his house for me and my men to spend the night?”

24.verse: Rebekah answered, “My father is Bethuel, the son of Milcah and Nahor.”

25.verse: Then she said, “And, yes, we have straw for your camels and a place for you to spend the night.”

26.verse: The servant bowed and worshiped the LORD

27.verse: and said, “Blessed is the LORD, the God of my master Abraham. The LORD has been kind and truthful to him and has led me to my master’s relatives.”

28.verse: Then Rebekah ran and told her mother’s family about all these things.

29.verse: She had a brother named Laban, who ran out to Abraham’s servant, who was still at the spring.

30.verse: Laban had heard what she had said and had seen the ring and the bracelets on his sister’s arms. So he ran out to the well, and there was the man standing by the camels at the spring.

31.verse: Laban said, “Sir, you are welcome to come in; you don’t have to stand outside. I have prepared the house for you and also a place for your camels.”

32.verse: So Abraham’s servant went into the house. After Laban unloaded the camels and gave them straw and food, he gave water to Abraham’s servant so he and the men with him could wash their feet.

33.verse: Then Laban gave the servant food, but the servant said, “I will not eat until I have told you why I came.” So Laban said, “Then tell us.”
