35.verse: The LORD has greatly blessed my master in everything, and he has become a rich man. The LORD has given him many flocks of sheep, herds of cattle, silver and gold, male and female servants, camels, and horses.

36.verse: Sarah, my master’s wife, gave birth to a son when she was old, and my master has given everything he owns to that son.

37.verse: My master had me make a promise to him and said, ‘Don’t get a wife for my son from the Canaanite girls who live around here.

38.verse: Instead, you must go to my father’s people and to my family. There you must get a wife for my son.’

39.verse: I said to my master, ‘What if the woman will not come back with me?’

40.verse: But he said, ‘I serve the LORD, who will send his angel with you and will help you. You will get a wife for my son from my family and my father’s people.

41.verse: Then you will be free from the promise. But if they will not give you a wife for my son, you will be free from this promise.’

42.verse: “Today I came to this spring. I said, ‘LORD, God of my master Abraham, please make my trip successful.

43.verse: I am standing by this spring. I will wait for a young woman to come out to get water, and I will say, “Please give me water from your jar to drink.”

44.verse: Then let her say, “Drink this water, and I will also get water for your camels.” By this I will know the LORD has chosen her for my master’s son.’

45.verse: “Before I finished my silent prayer, Rebekah came out of the city with her water jar on her shoulder. She went down to the spring and got water. I said to her, ‘Please give me a drink.’

46.verse: She quickly lowered the jar from her shoulder and said, ‘Drink this. I will also get water for your camels.’ So I drank, and she gave water to my camels too.

47.verse: When I asked her, ‘Who is your father?’ she answered, ‘My father is Bethuel son of Milcah and Nahor.’ Then I put the ring in her nose and the bracelets on her arms,

48.verse: and I bowed my head and thanked the LORD. I praised the LORD, the God of my master Abraham, because he led me on the right road to get the granddaughter of my master’s brother for his son.

49.verse: Now, tell me, will you be kind and truthful to my master? And if not, tell me so. Then I will know what I should do.”

50.verse: Laban and Bethuel answered, “This is clearly from the LORD, and we cannot change what must happen.

51.verse: Rebekah is yours. Take her and go. Let her marry your master’s son as the LORD has commanded.”

52.verse: When Abraham’s servant heard these words, he bowed facedown on the ground before the LORD.

53.verse: Then he gave Rebekah gold and silver jewelry and clothes. He also gave expensive gifts to her brother and mother.

54.verse: The servant and the men with him ate and drank and spent the night there. When they got up the next morning, the servant said, “Now let me go back to my master.”

55.verse: Rebekah’s mother and her brother said, “Let Rebekah stay with us at least ten days. After that she may go.”

56.verse: But the servant said to them, “Do not make me wait, because the LORD has made my trip successful. Now let me go back to my master.”

57.verse: Rebekah’s brother and mother said, “We will call Rebekah and ask her what she wants to do.”

58.verse: They called her and asked her, “Do you want to go with this man now?” She said, “Yes, I do.”

59.verse: So they allowed Rebekah and her nurse to go with Abraham’s servant and his men.

60.verse: They blessed Rebekah and said, “Our sister, may you be the mother of thousands of people, and may your descendants capture the cities of their enemies.”

61.verse: Then Rebekah and her servant girls got on the camels and followed the servant and his men. So the servant took Rebekah and left.

62.verse: At this time Isaac had left Beer Lahai Roi and was living in southern Canaan.

63.verse: One evening when he went out to the field to think, he looked up and saw camels coming.

64.verse: Rebekah also looked and saw Isaac. Then she jumped down from the camel

65.verse: and asked the servant, “Who is that man walking in the field to meet us?” The servant answered, “That is my master.” So Rebekah covered her face with her veil.

66.verse: The servant told Isaac everything that had happened.

67.verse: Then Isaac brought Rebekah into the tent of Sarah, his mother, and she became his wife. Isaac loved her very much, and so he was comforted after his mother’s death.

1.verse: Abraham’s Family - Abraham married again, and his new wife was Keturah.

2.verse: She gave birth to Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah.

3.verse: Jokshan was the father of Sheba and Dedan. Dedan’s descendants were the people of Assyria, Letush, and Leum.

4.verse: The sons of Midian were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah. All these were descendants of Keturah.

5.verse: Abraham left everything he owned to Isaac.

6.verse: But before Abraham died, he did give gifts to the sons of his other wives, then sent them to the East to be away from Isaac.

7.verse: Abraham lived to be one hundred seventy-five years old.

8.verse: He breathed his last breath and died at an old age, after a long and satisfying life.

9.verse: His sons Isaac and Ishmael buried him in the cave of Machpelah in the field of Ephron east of Mamre. (Ephron was the son of Zohar the Hittite.)

10.verse: So Abraham was buried with his wife Sarah in the same field that he had bought from the Hittites.

11.verse: After Abraham died, God blessed his son Isaac. Isaac was now living at Beer Lahai Roi.

12.verse: This is the family history of Ishmael, Abraham’s son. (Hagar, Sarah’s Egyptian servant, was Ishmael’s mother.)

13.verse: These are the names of Ishmael’s sons in the order they were born: Nebaioth, the first son, then Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,

14.verse: Mishma, Dumah, Massa,

15.verse: Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah.

16.verse: These were Ishmael’s sons, and these are the names of the tribal leaders listed according to their settlements and camps.

17.verse: Ishmael lived one hundred thirty-seven years and then breathed his last breath and died.

18.verse: His descendants lived from Havilah to Shur, which is east of Egypt stretching toward Assyria. They often attacked the descendants of his brothers.

19.verse: Isaac’s Family - This is the family history of Isaac. Abraham had a son named Isaac.

20.verse: When Isaac was forty years old, he married Rebekah, who came from Northwest Mesopotamia. She was Bethuel’s daughter and the sister of Laban the Aramean.

21.verse: Isaac’s wife could not have children, so Isaac prayed to the LORD for her. The LORD heard Isaac’s prayer, and Rebekah became pregnant.

22.verse: While she was pregnant, the babies struggled inside her. She asked, “Why is this happening to me?” Then she went to get an answer from the LORD.

23.verse: The LORD said to her, “Two nations are in your body, and two groups of people will be taken from you. One group will be stronger than the other, and the older will serve the younger.”

24.verse: When the time came, Rebekah gave birth to twins.

25.verse: The first baby was born red. Since his skin was like a hairy robe, he was named Esau.

26.verse: When the second baby was born, he was holding on to Esau’s heel, so that baby was named Jacob. Isaac was sixty years old when they were born.

27.verse: When the boys grew up, Esau became a skilled hunter. He loved to be out in the fields. But Jacob was a quiet man and stayed among the tents.

28.verse: Isaac loved Esau because he hunted the wild animals that Isaac enjoyed eating. But Rebekah loved Jacob.

29.verse: One day Jacob was boiling a pot of vegetable soup. Esau came in from hunting in the fields, weak from hunger.

30.verse: So Esau said to Jacob, “Let me eat some of that red soup, because I am weak with hunger.” (That is why people call him Edom.)

31.verse: But Jacob said, “You must sell me your rights as the firstborn son.”

32.verse: Esau said, “I am almost dead from hunger. If I die, all of my father’s wealth will not help me.”

33.verse: But Jacob said, “First, promise me that you will give it to me.” So Esau made a promise to Jacob and sold his part of their father’s wealth to Jacob.

34.verse: Then Jacob gave Esau bread and vegetable soup, and he ate and drank, and then left. So Esau showed how little he cared about his rights as the firstborn son.

1.verse: Isaac Lies to Abimelech - Now there was a time of hunger in the land, besides the time of hunger that happened during Abraham’s life. So Isaac went to the town of Gerar to see Abimelech king of the Philistines.

2.verse: The LORD appeared to Isaac and said, “Don’t go down to Egypt, but live in the land where I tell you to live.

3.verse: Stay in this land, and I will be with you and bless you. I will give you and your descendants all these lands, and I will keep the oath I made to Abraham your father.

4.verse: I will give you many descendants, as hard to count as the stars in the sky, and I will give them all these lands. Through your descendants all the nations on the earth will be blessed.

5.verse: I will do this because your father Abraham obeyed me. He did what I said and obeyed my commands, my teachings, and my rules.”

6.verse: So Isaac stayed in Gerar.

7.verse: His wife Rebekah was very beautiful, and the men of that place asked Isaac about her. Isaac said, “She is my sister,” because he was afraid to tell them she was his wife. He thought they might kill him so they could have her.

8.verse: Isaac lived there a long time. One day as Abimelech king of the Philistines looked out his window, he saw Isaac holding his wife Rebekah tenderly.

9.verse: Abimelech called for Isaac and said, “This woman is your wife. Why did you say she was your sister?” Isaac said to him, “I was afraid you would kill me so you could have her.”

10.verse: Abimelech said, “What have you done to us? One of our men might have had sexual relations with your wife. Then we would have been guilty of a great sin.”

11.verse: So Abimelech warned everyone, “Anyone who touches this man or his wife will be put to death.”

12.verse: Isaac Becomes Rich - Isaac planted seed in that land, and that year he gathered a great harvest. The LORD blessed him very much,

13.verse: and he became rich. He gathered more wealth until he became a very rich man.

14.verse: He had so many slaves and flocks and herds that the Philistines envied him.

15.verse: So they stopped up all the wells the servants of Isaac’s father Abraham had dug. (They had dug them when Abraham was alive.) The Philistines filled those wells with dirt.

16.verse: And Abimelech said to Isaac, “Leave our country because you have become much more powerful than we are.”

17.verse: So Isaac left that place and camped in the Valley of Gerar and lived there.

18.verse: Long before this time Abraham had dug many wells, but after he died, the Philistines filled them with dirt. So Isaac dug those wells again and gave them the same names his father had given them.

19.verse: Isaac’s servants dug a well in the valley, from which a spring of water flowed.

20.verse: But the herdsmen of Gerar argued with them and said, “This water is ours.” So Isaac named that well Argue because they argued with him.

21.verse: Then his servants dug another well. When the people also argued about it, Isaac named that well Fight.

22.verse: He moved from there and dug another well. No one argued about this one, so he named it Room Enough. Isaac said, “Now the LORD has made room for us, and we will be successful in this land.”

23.verse: From there Isaac went to Beersheba.

24.verse: The LORD appeared to him that night and said, “I am the God of your father Abraham. Don’t be afraid, because I am with you. I will bless you and give you many descendants because of my servant Abraham.”

25.verse: So Isaac built an altar and worshiped the LORD there. He also made a camp there, and his servants dug a well.

26.verse: Abimelech came from Gerar to see Isaac. He brought with him Ahuzzath, who advised him, and Phicol, the commander of his army.

27.verse: Isaac asked them, “Why have you come to see me? You were my enemy and forced me to leave your country.”

28.verse: They answered, “Now we know that the LORD is with you. Let us swear an oath to each other. Let us make an agreement with you

29.verse: that since we did not hurt you, you will not hurt us. We were good to you and sent you away in peace. Now the LORD has blessed you.”

30.verse: So Isaac prepared food for them, and they all ate and drank.

31.verse: Early the next morning the men swore an oath to each other. Then Isaac sent them away, and they left in peace.

32.verse: That day Isaac’s servants came and told him about the well they had dug, saying, “We found water in that well.”

33.verse: So Isaac named it Shibah and that city is called Beersheba even now.

34.verse: When Esau was forty years old, he married two Hittite women—Judith daughter of Beeri and Basemath daughter of Elon.

35.verse: These women brought much sorrow to Isaac and Rebekah.

1.verse: Jacob Tricks Isaac - When Isaac was old, his eyesight was poor, so he could not see clearly. One day he called his older son Esau to him and said, “Son.” Esau answered, “Here I am.”

2.verse: Isaac said, “I am old and don’t know when I might die.

3.verse: So take your bow and arrows and go hunting in the field for an animal for me to eat.

4.verse: When you prepare the tasty food that I love, bring it to me, and I will eat. Then I will bless you before I die.”

5.verse: So Esau went out in the field to hunt. Rebekah was listening as Isaac said this to his son Esau.

6.verse: She said to her son Jacob, “Listen, I heard your father saying to your brother Esau,

7.verse: ‘Kill an animal and prepare some tasty food for me to eat. Then I will bless you in the presence of the LORD before I die.’

8.verse: So obey me, my son, and do what I tell you.

9.verse: Go out to our goats and bring me two of the best young ones. I will prepare them just the way your father likes them.

10.verse: Then you will take the food to your father, and he will bless you before he dies.”

11.verse: But Jacob said to his mother Rebekah, “My brother Esau is a hairy man, and I am smooth!

12.verse: If my father touches me, he will know I am not Esau. Then he will not bless me but will place a curse on me because I tried to trick him.”

13.verse: So Rebekah said to him, “If your father puts a curse on you, I will accept the blame. Just do what I said. Go get the goats for me.”

14.verse: So Jacob went out and got two goats and brought them to his mother, and she cooked them in the special way Isaac enjoyed.

15.verse: She took the best clothes of her older son Esau that were in the house and put them on the younger son Jacob.

16.verse: She also took the skins of the goats and put them on Jacob’s hands and neck.

17.verse: Then she gave Jacob the tasty food and the bread she had made.

18.verse: Jacob went in to his father and said, “Father.” And his father said, “Yes, my son. Who are you?”

19.verse: Jacob said to him, “I am Esau, your first son. I have done what you told me. Now sit up and eat some meat of the animal I hunted for you. Then bless me.”

20.verse: But Isaac asked his son, “How did you find and kill the animal so quickly?” Jacob answered, “Because the LORD your God helped me to find it.”

21.verse: Then Isaac said to Jacob, “Come near so I can touch you, my son. Then I will know if you are really my son Esau.”

22.verse: So Jacob came near to Isaac his father. Isaac touched him and said, “Your voice sounds like Jacob’s voice, but your hands are hairy like the hands of Esau.”

23.verse: Isaac did not know it was Jacob, because his hands were hairy like Esau’s hands, so Isaac blessed him.

24.verse: Isaac asked, “Are you really my son Esau?” Jacob answered, “Yes, I am.”

25.verse: Then Isaac said, “Bring me the food, and I will eat it and bless you.” So Jacob gave him the food, and he ate. Jacob gave him wine, and he drank.

26.verse: Then Isaac said to him, “My son, come near and kiss me.”

27.verse: So Jacob went to his father and kissed him. When Isaac smelled Esau’s clothes, he blessed him and said, “The smell of my son is like the smell of the field that the LORD has blessed.

28.verse: May God give you plenty of rain and good soil so that you will have plenty of grain and new wine.

29.verse: May nations serve you and peoples bow down to you. May you be master over your brothers, and may your mother’s sons bow down to you. May everyone who curses you be cursed, and may everyone who blesses you be blessed.”

30.verse: Isaac finished blessing Jacob. Then, just as Jacob left his father Isaac, Esau came in from hunting.

31.verse: He also prepared some tasty food and brought it to his father. He said, “Father, rise and eat the food that your son killed for you and then bless me.”

32.verse: Isaac asked, “Who are you?” He answered, “I am your son—your firstborn son—Esau.”

33.verse: Then Isaac trembled greatly and said, “Then who was it that hunted the animals and brought me food before you came? I ate it, and I blessed him, and it is too late now to take back my blessing.”

34.verse: When Esau heard the words of his father, he let out a loud and bitter cry. He said to his father, “Bless me—me, too, my father!”

35.verse: But Isaac said, “Your brother came and tricked me. He has taken your blessing.”

36.verse: Esau said, “Jacob is the right name for him. He has tricked me these two times. He took away my share of everything you own, and now he has taken away my blessing.” Then Esau asked, “Haven’t you saved a blessing for me?”

37.verse: Isaac answered, “I gave Jacob the power to be master over you, and all his brothers will be his servants. And I kept him strong with grain and new wine. There is nothing left to give you, my son.”

38.verse: But Esau continued, “Do you have only one blessing, Father? Bless me, too, Father!” Then Esau began to cry out loud.

39.verse: Isaac said to him, “You will live far away from the best land, far from the rain.

40.verse: You will live by using your sword, and you will be a slave to your brother. But when you struggle, you will break free from him.”

41.verse: After that Esau hated Jacob because of the blessing from Isaac. He thought to himself, “My father will soon die, and I will be sad for him. Then I will kill Jacob.”

42.verse: Rebekah heard about Esau’s plan to kill Jacob. So she sent for Jacob and said to him, “Listen, your brother Esau is comforting himself by planning to kill you.

43.verse: So, my son, do what I say. My brother Laban is living in Haran. Go to him at once!

44.verse: Stay with him for a while, until your brother is not so angry.

45.verse: In time, your brother will not be angry, and he will forget what you did to him. Then I will send a servant to bring you back. I don’t want to lose both of my sons on the same day.”

46.verse: Then Rebekah said to Isaac, “I am tired of Hittite women. If Jacob marries one of these Hittite women here in this land, I want to die.”

1.verse: Jacob Searches for a Wife - Isaac called Jacob and blessed him and commanded him, “You must not marry a Canaanite woman.

2.verse: Go to the house of Bethuel, your mother’s father, in Northwest Mesopotamia. Laban, your mother’s brother, lives there. Marry one of his daughters.

3.verse: May God Almighty bless you and give you many children, and may you become a group of many peoples.

4.verse: May he give you and your descendants the blessing of Abraham so that you may own the land where you are now living as a stranger, the land God gave to Abraham.”

5.verse: So Isaac sent Jacob to Northwest Mesopotamia, to Laban the brother of Rebekah. Bethuel the Aramean was the father of Laban and Rebekah, and Rebekah was the mother of Jacob and Esau.

6.verse: Esau learned that Isaac had blessed Jacob and sent him to Northwest Mesopotamia to find a wife there. He also learned that Isaac had commanded Jacob not to marry a Canaanite woman

7.verse: and that Jacob had obeyed his father and mother and had gone to Northwest Mesopotamia.

8.verse: So Esau saw that his father Isaac did not want his sons to marry Canaanite women.

9.verse: Now Esau already had wives, but he went to Ishmael son of Abraham, and he married Mahalath, Ishmael’s daughter. Mahalath was the sister of Nebaioth.

10.verse: Jacob’s Dream at Bethel - Jacob left Beersheba and set out for Haran.

11.verse: When he came to a place, he spent the night there because the sun had set. He found a stone and laid his head on it to go to sleep.

12.verse: Jacob dreamed that there was a ladder resting on the earth and reaching up into heaven, and he saw angels of God going up and coming down the ladder.

13.verse: Then Jacob saw the LORD standing above the ladder, and he said, “I am the LORD, the God of Abraham your grandfather, and the God of Isaac. I will give you and your descendants the land on which you are now sleeping.

14.verse: Your descendants will be as many as the dust of the earth. They will spread west and east, north and south, and all the families of the earth will be blessed through you and your descendants.

15.verse: I am with you and will protect you everywhere you go and will bring you back to this land. I will not leave you until I have done what I have promised you.”

16.verse: Then Jacob woke from his sleep and said, “Surely the LORD is in this place, but I did not know it.”

17.verse: He was afraid and said, “This place frightens me! It is surely the house of God and the gate of heaven.”

18.verse: Jacob rose early in the morning and took the stone he had slept on and set it up on its end. Then he poured olive oil on the top of it.

19.verse: At first, the name of that city was Luz, but Jacob named it Bethel.

20.verse: Then Jacob made a promise. He said, “I want God to be with me and to protect me on this journey. I want him to give me food to eat and clothes to wear

21.verse: so I will be able to return in peace to my father’s house. If the LORD does these things, he will be my God.

22.verse: This stone which I have set up on its end will be the house of God. And I will give God one-tenth of all he gives me.”

1.verse: Jacob Arrives in Northwest Mesopotamia - Then Jacob continued his journey and came to the land of the people of the East.

2.verse: He looked and saw a well in the field and three flocks of sheep lying nearby, because they drank water from this well. A large stone covered the mouth of the well.

3.verse: When all the flocks would gather there, the shepherds would roll the stone away from the well and water the sheep. Then they would put the stone back in its place.

4.verse: Jacob said to the shepherds there, “My brothers, where are you from?” They answered, “We are from Haran.”

5.verse: Then Jacob asked, “Do you know Laban, grandson of Nahor?” They answered, “We know him.”

6.verse: Then Jacob asked, “How is he?” They answered, “He is well. Look, his daughter Rachel is coming now with his sheep.”

7.verse: Jacob said, “But look, it is still the middle of the day. It is not time for the sheep to be gathered for the night, so give them water and let them go back into the pasture.”

8.verse: But they said, “We cannot do that until all the flocks are gathered. Then we will roll away the stone from the mouth of the well and water the sheep.”

9.verse: While Jacob was talking with the shepherds, Rachel came with her father’s sheep, because it was her job to care for the sheep.

10.verse: When Jacob saw Laban’s daughter Rachel and Laban’s sheep, he went to the well and rolled the stone from its mouth and watered Laban’s sheep. Now Laban was the brother of Rebekah, Jacob’s mother.

11.verse: Then Jacob kissed Rachel and cried.

12.verse: He told her that he was from her father’s family and that he was the son of Rebekah. So Rachel ran home and told her father.

13.verse: When Laban heard the news about his sister’s son Jacob, he ran to meet him. Laban hugged him and kissed him and brought him to his house, where Jacob told Laban everything that had happened.

14.verse: Then Laban said, “You are my own flesh and blood.” Jacob Is Tricked - Jacob stayed there a month.

15.verse: Then Laban said to Jacob, “You are my relative, but it is not right for you to work for me without pay. What would you like me to pay you?”

16.verse: Now Laban had two daughters. The older was Leah, and the younger was Rachel.

17.verse: Leah had weak eyes, but Rachel was very beautiful.

18.verse: Jacob loved Rachel, so he said to Laban, “Let me marry your younger daughter Rachel. If you will, I will work seven years for you.”

19.verse: Laban said, “It would be better for her to marry you than someone else, so stay here with me.”

20.verse: So Jacob worked for Laban seven years so he could marry Rachel. But they seemed like just a few days to him because he loved Rachel very much.

21.verse: After seven years Jacob said to Laban, “Give me Rachel so that I may marry her. The time I promised to work for you is over.”

22.verse: So Laban gave a feast for all the people there.

23.verse: That evening he brought his daughter Leah to Jacob, and they had sexual relations.

24.verse: (Laban gave his slave girl Zilpah to his daughter to be her servant.)

25.verse: In the morning when Jacob saw that he had had sexual relations with Leah, he said to Laban, “What have you done to me? I worked hard for you so that I could marry Rachel! Why did you trick me?”

26.verse: Laban said, “In our country we do not allow the younger daughter to marry before the older daughter.

27.verse: But complete the full week of the marriage ceremony with Leah, and I will give you Rachel to marry also. But you must serve me another seven years.”

28.verse: So Jacob did this, and when he had completed the week with Leah, Laban gave him his daughter Rachel as a wife.

29.verse: (Laban gave his slave girl Bilhah to his daughter Rachel to be her servant.)

30.verse: So Jacob had sexual relations with Rachel also, and Jacob loved Rachel more than Leah. Jacob worked for Laban for another seven years.

31.verse: Jacob’s Family Grows - When the LORD saw that Jacob loved Rachel more than Leah, he made it possible for Leah to have children, but not Rachel.

32.verse: Leah became pregnant and gave birth to a son. She named him Reuben, because she said, “The LORD has seen my troubles. Surely now my husband will love me.”

33.verse: Leah became pregnant again and gave birth to another son. She named him Simeon and said, “The LORD has heard that I am not loved, so he has given me this son.”

34.verse: Leah became pregnant again and gave birth to another son. She named him Levi and said, “Now, surely my husband will be close to me, because I have given him three sons.”

35.verse: Then Leah gave birth to another son. She named him Judah, because she said, “Now I will praise the LORD.” Then Leah stopped having children.

1.verse: When Rachel saw that she was not having children for Jacob, she envied her sister Leah. She said to Jacob, “Give me children, or I’ll die!”

2.verse: Jacob became angry with her and said, “Can I do what only God can do? He is the one who has kept you from having children.”

3.verse: Then Rachel said, “Here is my slave girl Bilhah. Have sexual relations with her so she can give birth to a child for me. Then I can have my own family through her.”

4.verse: So Rachel gave Bilhah, her slave girl, to Jacob as a wife, and he had sexual relations with her.

5.verse: She became pregnant and gave Jacob a son.

6.verse: Rachel said, “God has judged me innocent. He has listened to my prayer and has given me a son,” so she named him Dan.

7.verse: Bilhah became pregnant again and gave Jacob a second son.

8.verse: Rachel said, “I have struggled hard with my sister, and I have won.” So she named that son Naphtali.

9.verse: Leah saw that she had stopped having children, so she gave her slave girl Zilpah to Jacob as a wife.

10.verse: When Zilpah had a son,

11.verse: Leah said, “I am lucky,” so she named him Gad.

12.verse: Zilpah gave birth to another son,

13.verse: and Leah said, “I am very happy! Now women will call me happy,” so she named him Asher.

14.verse: During the wheat harvest Reuben went into the field and found some mandrake plants and brought them to his mother Leah. But Rachel said to Leah, “Please give me some of your son’s mandrakes.”

15.verse: Leah answered, “You have already taken away my husband, and now you are trying to take away my son’s mandrakes.” But Rachel answered, “If you will give me your son’s mandrakes, you may sleep with Jacob tonight.”

16.verse: When Jacob came in from the field that night, Leah went out to meet him. She said, “You will have sexual relations with me tonight because I have paid for you with my son’s mandrakes.” So Jacob slept with her that night.

17.verse: Then God answered Leah’s prayer, and she became pregnant again. She gave birth to a fifth son

18.verse: and said, “God has given me what I paid for, because I gave my slave girl to my husband.” So Leah named her son Issachar.

19.verse: Leah became pregnant again and gave birth to a sixth son.

20.verse: She said, “God has given me a fine gift. Now surely Jacob will honor me, because I have given him six sons,” so she named him Zebulun.

21.verse: Later Leah gave birth to a daughter and named her Dinah.

22.verse: Then God remembered Rachel and answered her prayer, making it possible for her to have children.

23.verse: When she became pregnant and gave birth to a son, she said, “God has taken away my shame,”

24.verse: and she named him Joseph. Rachel said, “I wish the LORD would give me another son.”

25.verse: Jacob Tricks Laban - After the birth of Joseph, Jacob said to Laban, “Now let me go to my own home and country.

26.verse: Give me my wives and my children and let me go. I have earned them by working for you, and you know that I have served you well.”

27.verse: Laban said to him, “If I have pleased you, please stay. I know the LORD has blessed me because of you.

28.verse: Tell me what I should pay you, and I will give it to you.”

29.verse: Jacob answered, “You know that I have worked hard for you, and your flocks have grown while I cared for them.

30.verse: When I came, you had little, but now you have much. Every time I did something for you, the LORD blessed you. But when will I be able to do something for my own family?”

31.verse: Laban asked, “Then what should I give you?” Jacob answered, “I don’t want you to give me anything. Just do this one thing, and I will come back and take care of your flocks.

32.verse: Today let me go through all your flocks. I will take every speckled or spotted sheep, every black lamb, and every spotted or speckled goat. That will be my pay.

33.verse: In the future you can easily see if I am honest. When you come to look at my flocks, if I have any goat that isn’t speckled or spotted or any lamb that isn’t black, you will know I stole it.”

34.verse: Laban answered, “Agreed! We will do what you ask.”

35.verse: But that day Laban took away all the male goats that had streaks or spots, all the speckled and spotted female goats (all those that had white on them), and all the black sheep. He told his sons to watch over them.

36.verse: Then he took these animals to a place that was three days’ journey away from Jacob. Jacob took care of all the flocks that were left.

37.verse: So Jacob cut green branches from poplar, almond, and plane trees and peeled off some of the bark so that the branches had white stripes on them.

38.verse: He put the branches in front of the flocks at the watering places. When the animals came to drink, they also mated there,

39.verse: so the flocks mated in front of the branches. Then the young that were born were streaked, speckled, or spotted.

40.verse: Jacob separated the young animals from the others, and he made them face the streaked and dark animals in Laban’s flock. Jacob kept his animals separate from Laban’s.

41.verse: When the stronger animals in the flock were mating, Jacob put the branches before their eyes so they would mate near the branches.

42.verse: But when the weaker animals mated, Jacob did not put the branches there. So the animals born from the weaker animals were Laban’s, and those born from the stronger animals were Jacob’s.

43.verse: In this way Jacob became very rich. He had large flocks, many male and female servants, camels, and donkeys.

1.verse: Jacob Runs Away - One day Jacob heard Laban’s sons talking. They said, “Jacob has taken everything our father owned, and in this way he has become rich.”

2.verse: Then Jacob noticed that Laban was not as friendly as he had been before.

3.verse: The LORD said to Jacob, “Go back to the land where your ancestors lived, and I will be with you.”

4.verse: So Jacob told Rachel and Leah to meet him in the field where he kept his flocks.

5.verse: He said to them, “I have seen that your father is not as friendly with me as he used to be, but the God of my father has been with me.

6.verse: You both know that I have worked as hard as I could for your father,

7.verse: but he cheated me and changed my pay ten times. But God has not allowed your father to harm me.

8.verse: When Laban said, ‘You can have all the speckled animals as your pay,’ all the animals gave birth to speckled young ones. But when he said, ‘You can have all the streaked animals as your pay,’ all the flocks gave birth to streaked babies.

9.verse: So God has taken the animals away from your father and has given them to me.

10.verse: “I had a dream during the season when the flocks were mating. I saw that the only male goats who were mating were streaked, speckled, or spotted.

11.verse: The angel of God spoke to me in that dream and said, ‘Jacob!’ I answered, ‘Yes!’

12.verse: The angel said, ‘Look! Only the streaked, speckled, or spotted male goats are mating. I have seen all the wrong things Laban has been doing to you.

13.verse: I am the God who appeared to you at Bethel, where you poured olive oil on the stone you set up on end and where you made a promise to me. Now I want you to leave here and go back to the land where you were born.’”

14.verse: Rachel and Leah answered Jacob, “Our father has nothing to give us when he dies.

15.verse: He has treated us like strangers. He sold us to you, and then he spent all of the money you paid for us.

16.verse: God took all this wealth from our father, and now it belongs to us and our children. So do whatever God has told you to do.”

17.verse: So Jacob put his children and his wives on camels,

18.verse: and they began their journey back to Isaac, his father, in the land of Canaan. All the flocks of animals that Jacob owned walked ahead of them. He carried everything with him that he had gotten while he lived in Northwest Mesopotamia.

19.verse: While Laban was gone to cut the wool from his sheep, Rachel stole the idols that belonged to him.

20.verse: And Jacob tricked Laban the Aramean by not telling him he was leaving.

21.verse: Jacob and his family left quickly, crossed the Euphrates River, and traveled toward the mountains of Gilead.

22.verse: Three days later Laban learned that Jacob had run away,

23.verse: so he gathered his relatives and began to chase him. After seven days Laban found him in the mountains of Gilead.

24.verse: That night God came to Laban the Aramean in a dream and said, “Be careful! Do not say anything to Jacob, good or bad.”

25.verse: The Search for the Stolen Idols - So Laban caught up with Jacob. Now Jacob had made his camp in the mountains, so Laban and his relatives set up their camp in the mountains of Gilead.

26.verse: Laban said to Jacob, “What have you done? You cheated me and took my daughters as if you had captured them in a war.

27.verse: Why did you run away secretly and trick me? Why didn’t you tell me? Then I could have sent you away with joy and singing and with the music of tambourines and harps.

28.verse: You did not even let me kiss my grandchildren and my daughters good-bye. You were very foolish to do this!

29.verse: I have the power to harm you, but last night the God of your father spoke to me and warned me not to say anything to you, good or bad.

30.verse: I know you want to go back to your home, but why did you steal my idols?”

31.verse: Jacob answered Laban, “I left without telling you, because I was afraid you would take your daughters away from me.

32.verse: If you find anyone here who has taken your idols, that person will be killed! Your relatives will be my witnesses. You may look for anything that belongs to you and take anything that is yours.” (Now Jacob did not know that Rachel had stolen Laban’s idols.)

33.verse: So Laban looked in Jacob’s tent, in Leah’s tent, and in the tent where the two slave women stayed, but he did not find his idols. When he left Leah’s tent, he went into Rachel’s tent.

34.verse: Rachel had hidden the idols inside her camel’s saddle and was sitting on them. Although Laban looked through the whole tent, he did not find them.

35.verse: Rachel said to her father, “Father, don’t be angry with me. I am not able to stand up before you because I am having my monthly period.” So Laban looked through the camp, but he did not find his idols.

36.verse: Then Jacob became very angry and said, “What wrong have I done? What law have I broken to cause you to chase me?

37.verse: You have looked through everything I own, but you have found nothing that belongs to you. If you have found anything, show it to everyone. Put it in front of your relatives and my relatives, and let them decide which one of us is right.

38.verse: I have worked for you now for twenty years. During all that time none of the lambs and kids died during birth, and I have not eaten any of the male sheep from your flocks.

39.verse: Any time an animal was killed by wild beasts, I did not bring it to you, but made up for the loss myself. You made me pay for any animal that was stolen during the day or night.

40.verse: In the daytime the sun took away my strength, and at night I was cold and could not sleep.

41.verse: I worked like a slave for you for twenty years—the first fourteen to get your two daughters and the last six to earn your flocks. During that time you changed my pay ten times.

42.verse: But the God of my father, the God of Abraham and the God of Isaac, was with me. Otherwise, you would have sent me away with nothing. But he saw the trouble I had and the hard work I did, and last night he corrected you.”

43.verse: Jacob and Laban’s Agreement - Laban said to Jacob, “These girls are my daughters. Their children belong to me, and these flocks are mine. Everything you see here belongs to me, but I can do nothing to keep my daughters and their children.

44.verse: Let us make an agreement, and let us set up a pile of stones to remind us of it.”

45.verse: So Jacob took a large rock and set it up on its end.

46.verse: He told his relatives to gather rocks, so they took the rocks and piled them up; then they ate beside the pile.

47.verse: Laban named that place in his language A Pile to Remind Us, and Jacob gave the place the same name in Hebrew.

48.verse: Laban said to Jacob, “This pile of rocks will remind us of the agreement between us.” That is why the place was called A Pile to Remind Us.

49.verse: It was also called Mizpah, because Laban said, “Let the LORD watch over us while we are separated from each other.

50.verse: Remember that God is our witness even if no one else is around us. He will know if you harm my daughters or marry other women.

51.verse: Here is the pile of rocks that I have put between us and here is the rock I set up on end.

52.verse: This pile of rocks and this rock set on end will remind us of our agreement. I will never go past this pile to hurt you, and you must never come to my side of them to hurt me.

53.verse: Let the God of Abraham, who is the God of Nahor and the God of their ancestors, punish either of us if we break this agreement.” So Jacob made a promise in the name of the God whom his father Isaac worshiped.

54.verse: Then Jacob killed an animal and offered it as a sacrifice on the mountain, and he invited his relatives to share in the meal. After they finished eating, they spent the night on the mountain.

55.verse: Early the next morning Laban kissed his grandchildren and his daughters and blessed them, and then he left to return home.

1.verse: Jacob Meets Esau - When Jacob also went his way, the angels of God met him.

2.verse: When he saw them, he said, “This is the camp of God!” So he named that place Mahanaim.

3.verse: Jacob’s brother Esau was living in the area called Seir in the country of Edom. Jacob sent messengers to Esau,

4.verse: telling them, “Give this message to my master Esau: ‘This is what Jacob, your servant, says: I have lived with Laban and have remained there until now.

5.verse: I have cattle, donkeys, flocks, and male and female servants. I send this message to you and ask you to accept us.’”

6.verse: The messengers returned to Jacob and said, “We went to your brother Esau. He is coming to meet you and has four hundred men with him.”

7.verse: Then Jacob was very afraid and worried. He divided the people who were with him and all the flocks, herds, and camels into two camps.

8.verse: Jacob thought, “Esau might come and destroy one camp, but the other camp can run away and be saved.”

9.verse: Then Jacob said, “God of my father Abraham! God of my father Isaac! LORD, you told me to return to my country and my family. You said that you would treat me well.

10.verse: I am not worthy of the kindness and continual goodness you have shown me. The first time I traveled across the Jordan River, I had only my walking stick, but now I own enough to have two camps.

11.verse: Please save me from my brother Esau. I am afraid he will come and kill all of us, even the mothers with the children.

12.verse: You said to me, ‘I will treat you well and will make your children as many as the sand of the seashore. There will be too many to count.’”

13.verse: Jacob stayed there for the night and prepared a gift for Esau from what he had with him:

14.verse: two hundred female goats and twenty male goats, two hundred female sheep and twenty male sheep,

15.verse: thirty female camels and their young, forty cows and ten bulls, twenty female donkeys, and ten male donkeys.

16.verse: Jacob gave each separate flock of animals to one of his servants and said to them, “Go ahead of me and keep some space between each herd.”

17.verse: Jacob gave them their orders. To the servant with the first group of animals he said, “My brother Esau will come to you and ask, ‘Whose servant are you? Where are you going and whose animals are these?’

18.verse: Then you will answer, ‘They belong to your servant Jacob. He sent them as a gift to you, my master Esau, and he also is coming behind us.’”

19.verse: Jacob ordered the second servant, the third servant, and all the other servants to do the same thing. He said, “Say the same thing to Esau when you meet him.

20.verse: Say, ‘Your servant Jacob is coming behind us.’” Jacob thought, “If I send these gifts ahead of me, maybe Esau will forgive me. Then when I see him, perhaps he will accept me.”

21.verse: So Jacob sent the gifts to Esau, but he himself stayed that night in the camp.

22.verse: Jacob Wrestles with God - During the night Jacob rose and crossed the Jabbok River at the crossing, taking with him his two wives, his two slave girls, and his eleven sons.

23.verse: He sent his family and everything he had across the river.

24.verse: So Jacob was alone, and a man came and wrestled with him until the sun came up.

25.verse: When the man saw he could not defeat Jacob, he struck Jacob’s hip and put it out of joint.

26.verse: Then he said to Jacob, “Let me go. The sun is coming up.” But Jacob said, “I will let you go if you will bless me.”

27.verse: The man said to him, “What is your name?” And he answered, “Jacob.”

28.verse: Then the man said, “Your name will no longer be Jacob. Your name will now be Israel, because you have wrestled with God and with people, and you have won.”

29.verse: Then Jacob asked him, “Please tell me your name.” But the man said, “Why do you ask my name?” Then he blessed Jacob there.

30.verse: So Jacob named that place Peniel, saying, “I have seen God face to face, but my life was saved.”

31.verse: Then the sun rose as he was leaving that place, and Jacob was limping because of his leg.

32.verse: So even today the people of Israel do not eat the muscle that is on the hip joint of animals, because Jacob was touched there.

1.verse: Jacob Shows His Bravery - Jacob looked up and saw Esau coming, and with him were four hundred men. So Jacob divided his children among Leah, Rachel, and the two slave girls.

2.verse: Jacob put the slave girls with their children first, then Leah and her children behind them, and Rachel and Joseph last.

3.verse: Jacob himself went out in front of them and bowed down flat on the ground seven times as he was walking toward his brother.

4.verse: But Esau ran to meet Jacob and put his arms around him and hugged him. Then Esau kissed him, and they both cried.

5.verse: When Esau looked up and saw the women and children, he asked, “Who are these people with you?” Jacob answered, “These are the children God has given me. God has been good to me, your servant.”

6.verse: Then the two slave girls and their children came up to Esau and bowed down flat on the earth before him.

7.verse: Leah and her children also came up to Esau and also bowed down flat on the earth. Last of all, Joseph and Rachel came up to Esau, and they, too, bowed down flat before him.

8.verse: Esau said, “I saw many herds as I was coming here. Why did you bring them?” Jacob answered, “They were to please you, my master.”

9.verse: But Esau said, “I already have enough, my brother. Keep what you have.”

10.verse: Jacob said, “No! Please! If I have pleased you, then accept the gift I give you. I am very happy to see your face again. It is like seeing the face of God, because you have accepted me.

11.verse: So I beg you to accept the gift I give you. God has been very good to me, and I have more than I need.” And because Jacob begged, Esau accepted the gift.

12.verse: Then Esau said, “Let us be going. I will travel with you.”

13.verse: But Jacob said to him, “My master, you know that the children are weak. And I must be careful with my flocks and their young ones. If I force them to go too far in one day, all the animals will die.

14.verse: So, my master, you go on ahead of me, your servant. I will follow you slowly and let the animals and the children set the speed at which we travel. I will meet you, my master, in Edom.”

15.verse: So Esau said, “Then let me leave some of my people with you.” “No, thank you,” said Jacob. “I only want to please you, my master.”

16.verse: So that day Esau started back to Edom.

17.verse: But Jacob went to Succoth, where he built a house for himself and shelters for his animals. That is why the place was named Succoth.

18.verse: Jacob left Northwest Mesopotamia and arrived safely at the city of Shechem in the land of Canaan. There he camped east of the city.

19.verse: He bought a part of the field where he had camped from the sons of Hamor father of Shechem for one hundred pieces of silver.

20.verse: He built an altar there and named it after God, the God of Israel.

1.verse: Dinah Is Attacked - At this time Dinah, the daughter of Leah and Jacob, went out to visit the women of the land.

2.verse: When Shechem son of Hamor the Hivite, the ruler of the land, saw her, he took her and forced her to have sexual relations with him.

3.verse: Shechem fell in love with Dinah, and he spoke kindly to her.

4.verse: He told his father, Hamor, “Please get this girl for me so I can marry her.”

5.verse: Jacob learned how Shechem had disgraced his daughter, but since his sons were out in the field with the cattle, Jacob said nothing until they came home.

6.verse: While he waited, Hamor father of Shechem went to talk with Jacob.

7.verse: When Jacob’s sons heard what had happened, they came in from the field. They were very angry that Shechem had done such a wicked thing to Israel. It was wrong for him to have sexual relations with Jacob’s daughter; a thing like this should not be done.

8.verse: But Hamor talked to Dinah’s brothers and said, “My son Shechem is deeply in love with Dinah. Please let him marry her.

9.verse: Marry our people. Give your women to our men as wives and take our women for your men as wives.

10.verse: You can live in the same land with us. You will be free to own land and to trade here.”

11.verse: Shechem also talked to Jacob and to Dinah’s brothers and said, “Please accept my offer. I will give anything you ask.

12.verse: Ask as much as you want for the payment for the bride, and I will give it to you. Just let me marry Dinah.”

13.verse: Jacob’s sons answered Shechem and his father with lies, because Shechem had disgraced their sister Dinah.

14.verse: The brothers said to them, “We cannot allow you to marry our sister, because you are not circumcised. That would be a disgrace to us.

15.verse: But we will allow you to marry her if you do this one thing: Every man in your town must be circumcised like us.

16.verse: Then your men can marry our women, and our men can marry your women, and we will live in your land and become one people.

17.verse: If you refuse to be circumcised, we will take Dinah and leave.”

18.verse: What they asked seemed fair to Hamor and Shechem.

19.verse: So Shechem quickly went to be circumcised because he loved Jacob’s daughter. Now Shechem was the most respected man in his family.

20.verse: So Hamor and Shechem went to the gate of their city and spoke to the men of their city, saying,

21.verse: “These people want to be friends with us. So let them live in our land and trade here. There is enough land for all of us. Let us marry their women, and we can let them marry our women.

22.verse: But we must agree to one thing: All our men must be circumcised as they are. Then they will agree to live in our land, and we will be one people.

23.verse: If we do this, their cattle and their animals will belong to us. Let us do what they say, and they will stay in our land.”

24.verse: All the people who had come to the city gate heard this. They agreed with Hamor and Shechem, and every man was circumcised.

25.verse: Three days later the men who were circumcised were still in pain. Two of Jacob’s sons, Simeon and Levi (Dinah’s brothers), took their swords and made a surprise attack on the city, killing all the men there.

26.verse: They killed Hamor and his son Shechem and then took Dinah out of Shechem’s house and left.

27.verse: Jacob’s sons came upon the dead bodies and stole everything that was in the city, to pay them back for what Shechem had done to their sister.

28.verse: So the brothers took the flocks, herds, and donkeys, and everything in the city and in the fields.

29.verse: They took every valuable thing the people owned, even their wives and children and everything in the houses.

30.verse: Then Jacob said to Simeon and Levi, “You have caused me a lot of trouble. Now the Canaanites and the Perizzites who live in the land will hate me. Since there are only a few of us, if they join together to attack us, my people and I will be destroyed.”

31.verse: But the brothers said, “We will not allow our sister to be treated like a prostitute.”

1.verse: Jacob in Bethel - God said to Jacob, “Go to the city of Bethel and live there. Make an altar to the God who appeared to you there when you were running away from your brother Esau.”

2.verse: So Jacob said to his family and to all who were with him, “Put away the foreign gods you have, and make yourselves clean, and change your clothes.

3.verse: We will leave here and go to Bethel. There I will build an altar to God, who has helped me during my time of trouble. He has been with me everywhere I have gone.”

4.verse: So they gave Jacob all the foreign gods they had, and the earrings they were wearing, and he hid them under the great tree near the town of Shechem.

5.verse: Then Jacob and his sons left there. But God caused the people in the nearby cities to be afraid, so they did not follow them.

6.verse: And Jacob and all the people who were with him went to Luz, which is now called Bethel, in the land of Canaan.

7.verse: There Jacob built an altar and named the place Bethel, after God, because God had appeared to him there when he was running from his brother.

8.verse: Deborah, Rebekah’s nurse, died and was buried under the oak tree at Bethel, so they named that place Oak of Crying.

9.verse: Jacob’s New Name - When Jacob came back from Northwest Mesopotamia, God appeared to him again and blessed him.

10.verse: God said to him, “Your name is Jacob, but you will not be called Jacob any longer. Your new name will be Israel.” So he called him Israel.

11.verse: God said to him, “I am God Almighty. Have many children and grow in number as a nation. You will be the ancestor of many nations and kings.

12.verse: The same land I gave to Abraham and Isaac I will give to you and your descendants.”

13.verse: Then God left him.

14.verse: Jacob set up a stone on edge in that place where God had talked to him, and he poured a drink offering and olive oil on it to make it special for God.

15.verse: And Jacob named the place Bethel.

16.verse: Rachel Dies Giving Birth - Jacob and his group left Bethel. Before they came to Ephrath, Rachel began giving birth to her baby,

17.verse: but she was having much trouble. When Rachel’s nurse saw this, she said, “Don’t be afraid, Rachel. You are giving birth to another son.”

18.verse: Rachel gave birth to the son, but she herself died. As she lay dying, she named the boy Son of My Suffering, but Jacob called him Benjamin.

19.verse: Rachel was buried on the road to Ephrath, a district of Bethlehem,

20.verse: and Jacob set up a rock on her grave to honor her. That rock is still there.

21.verse: Then Israel continued his journey and camped just south of Migdal Eder.

22.verse: While Israel was there, Reuben had sexual relations with Israel’s slave woman Bilhah, and Israel heard about it. The Family of Israel - Jacob had twelve sons.

23.verse: He had six sons by his wife Leah: Reuben, his first son, then Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, and Zebulun.

24.verse: He had two sons by his wife Rachel: Joseph and Benjamin.

25.verse: He had two sons by Rachel’s slave girl Bilhah: Dan and Naphtali.

26.verse: And he had two sons by Leah’s slave girl Zilpah: Gad and Asher. These are Jacob’s sons who were born in Northwest Mesopotamia.

27.verse: Jacob went to his father Isaac at Mamre near Hebron, where Abraham and Isaac had lived.

28.verse: Isaac lived one hundred eighty years.

29.verse: So Isaac breathed his last breath and died when he was very old, and his sons Esau and Jacob buried him.

1.verse: Esau’s Family - This is the family history of Esau (also called Edom).

2.verse: Esau married women from the land of Canaan: Adah daughter of Elon the Hittite; and Oholibamah daughter of Anah, the son of Zibeon the Hivite;

3.verse: and Basemath, Ishmael’s daughter, the sister of Nebaioth.

4.verse: Adah gave birth to Eliphaz for Esau. Basemath gave him Reuel,

5.verse: and Oholibamah gave him Jeush, Jalam, and Korah. These were Esau’s sons who were born in the land of Canaan.

6.verse: Esau took his wives, his sons, his daughters, and all the people who lived with him, his herds and other animals, and all the belongings he had gotten in Canaan, and he went to a land away from his brother Jacob.

7.verse: Esau and Jacob’s belongings were becoming too many for them to live in the same land. The land where they had lived could not support both of them, because they had too many herds.

8.verse: So Esau lived in the mountains of Edom. (Esau is also named Edom.)

9.verse: This is the family history of Esau. He is the ancestor of the Edomites, who live in the mountains of Edom.

10.verse: Esau’s sons were Eliphaz, son of Adah and Esau, and Reuel, son of Basemath and Esau.

11.verse: Eliphaz had five sons: Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam, and Kenaz.

12.verse: Eliphaz also had a slave woman named Timna, and Timna and Eliphaz gave birth to Amalek. These were Esau’s grandsons by his wife Adah.

13.verse: Reuel had four sons: Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. These were Esau’s grandsons by his wife Basemath.

14.verse: Esau’s third wife was Oholibamah the daughter of Anah. (Anah was the son of Zibeon.) Esau and Oholibamah gave birth to Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.

15.verse: These were the leaders that came from Esau: Esau’s first son was Eliphaz. From him came these leaders: Teman, Omar, Zepho, Kenaz,

16.verse: Korah, Gatam, and Amalek. These were the leaders that came from Eliphaz in the land of Edom. They were the grandsons of Adah.

17.verse: Esau’s son Reuel was the father of these leaders: Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. These were the leaders that came from Reuel in the land of Edom. They were the grandsons of Esau’s wife Basemath.

18.verse: Esau’s wife Oholibamah gave birth to these leaders: Jeush, Jalam, and Korah. These are the leaders that came from Esau’s wife Oholibamah the daughter of Anah.

19.verse: These were the sons of Esau (also called Edom), and these were their leaders.

20.verse: These were the sons of Seir the Horite, who were living in the land: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,

21.verse: Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan. These sons of Seir were the leaders of the Horites in Edom.

22.verse: The sons of Lotan were Hori and Homam. (Timna was Lotan’s sister.)

23.verse: The sons of Shobal were Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho, and Onam.

24.verse: The sons of Zibeon were Aiah and Anah. Anah is the man who found the hot springs in the desert while he was caring for his father’s donkeys.

25.verse: The children of Anah were Dishon and Oholibamah daughter of Anah.

26.verse: The sons of Dishon were Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Keran.

27.verse: The sons of Ezer were Bilhan, Zaavan, and Akan.

28.verse: The sons of Dishan were Uz and Aran.

29.verse: These were the names of the Horite leaders: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,

30.verse: Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan. These men were the leaders of the Horite families who lived in the land of Edom.

31.verse: These are the kings who ruled in the land of Edom before the Israelites ever had a king:

32.verse: Bela son of Beor was the king of Edom. He came from the city of Dinhabah.

33.verse: When Bela died, Jobab son of Zerah became king. Jobab was from Bozrah.

34.verse: When Jobab died, Husham became king. He was from the land of the Temanites.

35.verse: When Husham died, Hadad son of Bedad, who had defeated Midian in the country of Moab, became king. Hadad was from the city of Avith.

36.verse: When Hadad died, Samlah became king. He was from Masrekah.

37.verse: When Samlah died, Shaul became king. He was from Rehoboth on the Euphrates River.

38.verse: When Shaul died, Baal-Hanan son of Acbor became king.

39.verse: When Baal-Hanan son of Acbor died, Hadad became king. He was from the city of Pau. His wife’s name was Mehetabel daughter of Matred, who was the daughter of Me-Zahab.

40.verse: These Edomite leaders, listed by their families and regions, came from Esau. Their names were Timna, Alvah, Jetheth,

43.verse: Magdiel, and Iram. They were the leaders of Edom. (Esau was the father of the Edomites.) The area where each of these families lived was named after that family.

1.verse: Joseph the Dreamer - Jacob lived in the land of Canaan, where his father had lived.

2.verse: This is the family history of Jacob: Joseph was a young man, seventeen years old. He and his brothers, the sons of Bilhah and Zilpah, his father’s wives, cared for the flocks. Joseph gave his father bad reports about his brothers.

3.verse: Since Joseph was born when his father Israel was old, Israel loved him more than his other sons. He made Joseph a special robe with long sleeves.

4.verse: When Joseph’s brothers saw that their father loved him more than he loved them, they hated their brother and could not speak to him politely.

5.verse: One time Joseph had a dream, and when he told his brothers about it, they hated him even more.

6.verse: Joseph said, “Listen to the dream I had.

7.verse: We were in the field tying bundles of wheat together. My bundle stood up, and your bundles of wheat gathered around it and bowed down to it.”

8.verse: His brothers said, “Do you really think you will be king over us? Do you truly think you will rule over us?” His brothers hated him even more because of his dreams and what he had said.

9.verse: Then Joseph had another dream, and he told his brothers about it also. He said, “Listen, I had another dream. I saw the sun, moon, and eleven stars bowing down to me.”

10.verse: Joseph also told his father about this dream, but his father scolded him, saying, “What kind of dream is this? Do you really believe that your mother, your brothers, and I will bow down to you?”

11.verse: Joseph’s brothers were jealous of him, but his father thought about what all these things could mean.

12.verse: One day Joseph’s brothers went to Shechem to graze their father’s flocks.

13.verse: Israel said to Joseph, “Go to Shechem where your brothers are grazing the flocks.” Joseph answered, “I will go.”

14.verse: His father said, “Go and see if your brothers and the flocks are all right. Then come back and tell me.” So Joseph’s father sent him from the Valley of Hebron. When Joseph came to Shechem,

15.verse: a man found him wandering in the field and asked him, “What are you looking for?”

16.verse: Joseph answered, “I am looking for my brothers. Can you tell me where they are grazing the flocks?”

17.verse: The man said, “They have already gone. I heard them say they were going to Dothan.” So Joseph went to look for his brothers and found them in Dothan.

18.verse: Joseph Sold into Slavery - Joseph’s brothers saw him coming from far away. Before he reached them, they made a plan to kill him.

19.verse: They said to each other, “Here comes that dreamer.

20.verse: Let’s kill him and throw his body into one of the wells. We can tell our father that a wild animal killed him. Then we will see what will become of his dreams.”

21.verse: But Reuben heard their plan and saved Joseph, saying, “Let’s not kill him.

22.verse: Don’t spill any blood. Throw him into this well here in the desert, but don’t hurt him!” Reuben planned to save Joseph later and send him back to his father.

23.verse: So when Joseph came to his brothers, they pulled off his robe with long sleeves

24.verse: and threw him into the well. It was empty, and there was no water in it.

25.verse: While Joseph was in the well, the brothers sat down to eat. When they looked up, they saw a group of Ishmaelites traveling from Gilead to Egypt. Their camels were carrying spices, balm, and myrrh.

26.verse: Then Judah said to his brothers, “What will we gain if we kill our brother and hide his death?

27.verse: Let’s sell him to these Ishmaelites. Then we will not be guilty of killing our own brother. After all, he is our brother, our own flesh and blood.” And the other brothers agreed.

28.verse: So when the Midianite traders came by, the brothers took Joseph out of the well and sold him to the Ishmaelites for eight ounces of silver. And the Ishmaelites took him to Egypt.

29.verse: When Reuben came back to the well and Joseph was not there, he tore his clothes to show he was upset.

30.verse: Then he went back to his brothers and said, “The boy is not there! What shall I do?”

31.verse: The brothers killed a goat and dipped Joseph’s robe in its blood.

32.verse: Then they brought the long-sleeved robe to their father and said, “We found this robe. Look it over carefully and see if it is your son’s robe.”

33.verse: Jacob looked it over and said, “It is my son’s robe! Some savage animal has eaten him. My son Joseph has been torn to pieces!”

34.verse: Then Jacob tore his clothes and put on rough cloth to show that he was upset, and he continued to be sad about his son for a long time.

35.verse: All of his sons and daughters tried to comfort him, but he could not be comforted. He said, “I will be sad about my son until the day I die.” So Jacob cried for his son Joseph.

36.verse: Meanwhile the Midianites who had bought Joseph had taken him to Egypt. There they sold him to Potiphar, an officer to the king of Egypt and captain of the palace guard.

1.verse: Judah and Tamar - About that time, Judah left his brothers and went to stay with a man named Hirah in the town of Adullam.

2.verse: There Judah met a Canaanite girl, the daughter of a man named Shua, and married her. Judah had sexual relations with her,

3.verse: and she became pregnant and gave birth to a son, whom Judah named Er.

4.verse: Later she gave birth to another son and named him Onan.

5.verse: Still later she had another son and named him Shelah. She was at Kezib when this third son was born.

6.verse: Judah chose a girl named Tamar to be the wife of his first son Er.

7.verse: But Er, Judah’s oldest son, did what the LORD said was evil, so the LORD killed him.

8.verse: Then Judah said to Er’s brother Onan, “Go and have sexual relations with your dead brother’s wife. It is your duty to provide children for your brother in this way.”

9.verse: But Onan knew that the children would not belong to him, so when he was supposed to have sexual relations with Tamar he did not complete the sex act. This made it impossible for Tamar to become pregnant and for Er to have descendants.

10.verse: The LORD was displeased by this wicked thing Onan had done, so the LORD killed Onan also.

11.verse: Then Judah said to his daughter-in-law Tamar, “Go back to live in your father’s house, and don’t marry until my young son Shelah grows up.” Judah was afraid that Shelah also would die like his brothers. So Tamar returned to her father’s home.

12.verse: After a long time Judah’s wife, the daughter of Shua, died. After Judah had gotten over his sorrow, he went to Timnah to his men who were cutting the wool from his sheep. His friend Hirah from Adullam went with him.

13.verse: Tamar learned that Judah, her father-in-law, was going to Timnah to cut the wool from his sheep.

14.verse: So she took off the clothes that showed she was a widow and covered her face with a veil to hide who she was. Then she sat down by the gate of Enaim on the road to Timnah. She did this because Judah’s younger son Shelah had grown up, but Judah had not made plans for her to marry him.

15.verse: When Judah saw her, he thought she was a prostitute, because she had covered her face with a veil.

16.verse: So Judah went to her and said, “Let me have sexual relations with you.” He did not know that she was Tamar, his daughter-in-law. She asked, “What will you give me if I let you have sexual relations with me?”

17.verse: Judah answered, “I will send you a young goat from my flock.” She answered, “First give me something to keep as a deposit until you send the goat.”

18.verse: Judah asked, “What do you want me to give you as a deposit?” Tamar answered, “Give me your seal and its cord, and give me your walking stick.” So Judah gave these things to her. Then Judah and Tamar had sexual relations, and Tamar became pregnant.

19.verse: When Tamar went home, she took off the veil that covered her face and put on the clothes that showed she was a widow.

20.verse: Judah sent his friend Hirah with the young goat to find the woman and get back his seal and the walking stick he had given her, but Hirah could not find her.

21.verse: He asked some of the people at the town of Enaim, “Where is the prostitute who was here by the road?” They answered, “There has never been a prostitute here.”

22.verse: So he went back to Judah and said, “I could not find the woman, and the people who lived there said, ‘There has never been a prostitute here.’”

23.verse: Judah said, “Let her keep the things. I don’t want people to laugh at us. I sent her the goat as I promised, but you could not find her.”

24.verse: About three months later someone told Judah, “Tamar, your daughter-in-law, is guilty of acting like a prostitute, and now she is pregnant.” Then Judah said, “Bring her out and let her be burned to death.”

25.verse: When the people went to bring Tamar out, she sent a message to her father-in-law that said, “The man who owns these things has made me pregnant. Look at this seal and its cord and this walking stick, and tell me whose they are.”

26.verse: Judah recognized them and said, “She is more in the right than I. She did this because I did not give her to my son Shelah as I promised.” And Judah did not have sexual relations with her again.

27.verse: When the time came for Tamar to give birth, there were twins in her body.

28.verse: While she was giving birth, one baby put his hand out. The nurse tied a red string on his hand and said, “This baby came out first.”

29.verse: But he pulled his hand back in, so the other baby was born first. The nurse said, “So you are able to break out first,” and they named him Perez.

30.verse: After this, the baby with the red string on his hand was born, and they named him Zerah.

1.verse: Joseph Is Sold to Potiphar - Now Joseph had been taken down to Egypt. An Egyptian named Potiphar was an officer to the king of Egypt and the captain of the palace guard. He bought Joseph from the Ishmaelites who had brought him down there.

2.verse: The LORD was with Joseph, and he became a successful man. He lived in the house of his master, Potiphar the Egyptian.

3.verse: Potiphar saw that the LORD was with Joseph and that the LORD made Joseph successful in everything he did.

4.verse: So Potiphar was very happy with Joseph and allowed him to be his personal servant. He put Joseph in charge of the house, trusting him with everything he owned.

5.verse: When Joseph was put in charge of the house and everything Potiphar owned, the LORD blessed the people in Potiphar’s house because of Joseph. And the LORD blessed everything that belonged to Potiphar, both in the house and in the field.

6.verse: So Potiphar left Joseph in charge of everything he owned and was not concerned about anything except the food he ate. Joseph Is Put into Prison - Now Joseph was well built and handsome.

7.verse: After some time the wife of Joseph’s master began to desire Joseph, and one day she said to him, “Have sexual relations with me.”

8.verse: But Joseph refused and said to her, “My master trusts me with everything in his house. He has put me in charge of everything he owns.

9.verse: There is no one in his house greater than I. He has not kept anything from me except you, because you are his wife. How can I do such an evil thing? It is a sin against God.”

10.verse: The woman talked to Joseph every day, but he refused to have sexual relations with her or even spend time with her.

11.verse: One day Joseph went into the house to do his work as usual and was the only man in the house at that time.

12.verse: His master’s wife grabbed his coat and said to him, “Come and have sexual relations with me.” But Joseph left his coat in her hand and ran out of the house.

13.verse: When she saw that Joseph had left his coat in her hands and had run outside,

14.verse: she called to the servants in her house and said, “Look! This Hebrew slave was brought here to shame us. He came in and tried to have sexual relations with me, but I screamed.

15.verse: My scream scared him and he ran away, but he left his coat with me.”

16.verse: She kept his coat until her husband came home,

17.verse: and she told him the same story. She said, “This Hebrew slave you brought here came in to shame me!

18.verse: When he came near me, I screamed. He ran away, but he left his coat.”

19.verse: When Joseph’s master heard what his wife said Joseph had done, he became very angry.

20.verse: So Potiphar arrested Joseph and put him into the prison where the king’s prisoners were put. And Joseph stayed there in the prison.

21.verse: But the LORD was with Joseph and showed him kindness and caused the prison warden to like Joseph.

22.verse: The prison warden chose Joseph to take care of all the prisoners, and he was responsible for whatever was done in the prison.

23.verse: The warden paid no attention to anything that was in Joseph’s care because the LORD was with Joseph and made him successful in everything he did.

1.verse: Joseph Interprets Two Dreams - After these things happened, two of the king’s officers displeased the king—the man who served wine to the king and the king’s baker.

2.verse: The king became angry with his officer who served him wine and his baker,

3.verse: so he put them in the prison of the captain of the guard, the same prison where Joseph was kept.

4.verse: The captain of the guard put the two prisoners in Joseph’s care, and they stayed in prison for some time.

5.verse: One night both the king’s officer who served him wine and the baker had a dream. Each had his own dream with its own meaning.

6.verse: When Joseph came to them the next morning, he saw they were worried.

7.verse: He asked the king’s officers who were with him, “Why do you look so unhappy today?”

8.verse: The two men answered, “We both had dreams last night, but no one can explain their meaning to us.” Joseph said to them, “God is the only One who can explain the meaning of dreams. Tell me your dreams.”

9.verse: So the man who served wine to the king told Joseph his dream. He said, “I dreamed I saw a vine, and

10.verse: on the vine were three branches. I watched the branches bud and blossom, and then the grapes ripened.

11.verse: I was holding the king’s cup, so I took the grapes and squeezed the juice into the cup. Then I gave it to the king.”

12.verse: Then Joseph said, “I will explain the dream to you. The three branches stand for three days.

13.verse: Before the end of three days the king will free you, and he will allow you to return to your work. You will serve the king his wine just as you did before.

14.verse: But when you are free, remember me. Be kind to me, and tell the king about me so I can get out of this prison.

15.verse: I was taken by force from the land of the Hebrews, and I have done nothing here to deserve being put in prison.”

16.verse: The baker saw that Joseph’s explanation of the dream was good, so he said to him, “I also had a dream. I dreamed there were three bread baskets on my head.

17.verse: In the top basket were all kinds of baked food for the king, but the birds were eating this food out of the basket on my head.”

18.verse: Joseph answered, “I will tell you what the dream means. The three baskets stand for three days.

19.verse: Before the end of three days, the king will cut off your head! He will hang your body on a pole, and the birds will eat your flesh.”

20.verse: Three days later, on his birthday, the king gave a feast for all his officers. In front of his officers, he released from prison the chief officer who served his wine and the chief baker.

21.verse: The king gave his chief officer who served wine his old position, and once again he put the king’s cup of wine into the king’s hand.

22.verse: But the king hanged the baker on a pole. Everything happened just as Joseph had said it would,

23.verse: but the officer who served wine did not remember Joseph. He forgot all about him.

1.verse: The King’s Dreams - Two years later the king dreamed he was standing on the bank of the Nile River.

2.verse: He saw seven fat and beautiful cows come up out of the river, and they stood there, eating the grass.

3.verse: Then seven more cows came up out of the river, but they were thin and ugly. They stood beside the seven beautiful cows on the bank of the Nile.

4.verse: The seven thin and ugly cows ate the seven beautiful fat cows. Then the king woke up.

5.verse: The king slept again and dreamed a second time. In his dream he saw seven full and good heads of grain growing on one stalk.

6.verse: After that, seven more heads of grain sprang up, but they were thin and burned by the hot east wind.

7.verse: The thin heads of grain ate the seven full and good heads. Then the king woke up again, and he realized it was only a dream.

8.verse: The next morning the king was troubled about these dreams, so he sent for all the magicians and wise men of Egypt. The king told them his dreams, but no one could explain their meaning to him.

9.verse: Then the chief officer who served wine to the king said to him, “Now I remember something I promised to do, but I forgot about it.

10.verse: There was a time when you were angry with the baker and me, and you put us in prison in the house of the captain of the guard.

11.verse: In prison we each had a dream on the same night, and each dream had a different meaning.

12.verse: A young Hebrew man, a servant of the captain of the guard, was in the prison with us. When we told him our dreams, he explained their meanings to us. He told each man the meaning of his dream, and

13.verse: things happened exactly as he said they would: I was given back my old position, and the baker was hanged.”

14.verse: So the king called for Joseph. The guards quickly brought him out of the prison, and he shaved, put on clean clothes, and went before the king.

15.verse: The king said to Joseph, “I have had a dream, but no one can explain its meaning to me. I have heard that you can explain a dream when someone tells it to you.”

16.verse: Joseph answered the king, “I am not able to explain the meaning of dreams, but God will do this for the king.”

17.verse: Then the king said to Joseph, “In my dream I was standing on the bank of the Nile River.

18.verse: I saw seven fat and beautiful cows that came up out of the river and ate the grass.

19.verse: Then I saw seven more cows come out of the river that were thin and lean and ugly—the worst looking cows I have seen in all the land of Egypt.

20.verse: And these thin and ugly cows ate the first seven fat cows,

21.verse: but after they had eaten the seven cows, no one could tell they had eaten them. They looked just as thin and ugly as they did in the beginning. Then I woke up.

22.verse: “I had another dream. I saw seven full and good heads of grain growing on one stalk.

23.verse: Then seven more heads of grain sprang up after them, but these heads were thin and ugly and were burned by the hot east wind.

24.verse: Then the thin heads ate the seven good heads. I told this dream to the magicians, but no one could explain its meaning to me.”

25.verse: Joseph Tells the Dreams’ Meaning - Then Joseph said to the king, “Both of these dreams mean the same thing. God is telling you what he is about to do.

26.verse: The seven good cows stand for seven years, and the seven good heads of grain stand for seven years. Both dreams mean the same thing.

27.verse: The seven thin and ugly cows stand for seven years, and the seven thin heads of grain burned by the hot east wind stand for seven years of hunger.

28.verse: This will happen as I told you. God is showing the king what he is about to do.

29.verse: You will have seven years of good crops and plenty to eat in all the land of Egypt.

30.verse: But after those seven years, there will come seven years of hunger, and all the food that grew in the land of Egypt will be forgotten. The time of hunger will eat up the land.

31.verse: People will forget what it was like to have plenty of food, because the hunger that follows will be so great.
